'''Adelaide Women's Club''' was a social club for women which operated from 1922 to 1938 in [[Adelaide, South Australia]].
==History== The Adelaide Women's Club was founded in June 1922 by a handful of professional women led by [[Adelaide Miethke]], and incorporated later the same year.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article63927150 |title=Advertising |newspaper=[[The Register (Adelaide)]] |volume=LXXXVII, |issue=25,484 |location=South Australia |date=31 August 1922 |accessdate=22 May 2016 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Club premises were located in upstairs rooms previously operated by the [[YWCA]] on Grenfell Street, but soon moved to what had been Beaches Restaurant on Hindley Street, about 100 metres from King William Street. Its membership was drawn from Adelaide's business, public, professional, scientific, literary, and artistic communities, but also welcomed married women with "home duties". The Club was founded with 163 members, and by September 1923 had grown to 281. Membership was £1 a year, and the entrance fee 2/6. Facilities included library, drawing rooms, dressing rooms and a cafeteria. By March 1930 membership had grown to 320.<ref name=peel/>
The foundation committee consisted of secretary/manager E. Gill (Eileen?), and president Adelaide Miethke, with two vice presidents [[Amy Tomkinson]] and [[Phebe Watson]], treasurer Gertrude May Fulston JP (1893–1954), and six ordinary members. Trustees were Adelaide Miethke, Phebe Watson, Gertrude May Fulston, and [[Mabel Gilbert]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article63783426 |title=How Women Club in Adelaide |newspaper=[[The Mail (Adelaide)]] |volume=12, |issue=593 |location=South Australia |date=22 September 1923 |accessdate=7 March 2016 |page=3 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Committee membership remained stable for many years, with [[Meta Buring]] (1875–1955) being one of the few new faces.
In 1930 a wall of their building collapsed, followed by a fire,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article73790998 |title=Adelaide Women's Club: Vicissitudes and Victory |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)]] |location=South Australia |date=25 March 1930 |accessdate=22 May 2016 |page=7 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> and the committee saw this as an opportunity to move from Hindley Street to larger premises in the White Hart building, Peel Street, just around the corner; additional facilities included a bathroom, five bedrooms and a balcony.<ref name=peel>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article128986414 |title=Women's Club |newspaper=[[The News (Adelaide)]] |volume=XIV, |issue=2,073 |location=South Australia |date=8 March 1930 |accessdate=22 May 2016 |page=2 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> With the new premises, the Club enjoyed a surge in membership, and Mrs. Decimus Smith, née Irene France (1884–1966) was appointed business manager. Prominent members from around this time were the singer [[Charlotte Grivell]] (1901–1981) and [[Lady Hore-Ruthven]] (also known as Lady Gowrie).
For practically the whole life of the Club, [[Alliance Française]] met at the Club rooms.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article132204744 |title=Social Chat for Women |newspaper=[[The News (Adelaide)]] |volume=XXVI, |issue=4,003 |location=South Australia |date=21 May 1936 |accessdate=22 May 2016 |page=18 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Other organizations to use the Club's facilities were the United Arts Club,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article128987871 |title=United Arts Club |newspaper=[[The News (Adelaide)]] |volume=XIV, |issue=2,071 |location=South Australia |date=6 March 1930 |accessdate=22 May 2016 |page=6 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> and the National Council of Women also held their meetings at the Club, which they made their headquarters.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article37287840 |title=Women's Centenary Council |newspaper=[[The Advertiser (Adelaide)]] |location=South Australia |date=15 May 1935 |accessdate=22 May 2016 |page=21 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> Various Old Scholars' groups held their reunions there, as did the [[Advanced School for Girls]] for their annual bridge night,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article131919747 |title=Bridge Party For Old Scholars |newspaper=[[The News (Adelaide)]] |volume=XXXI, |issue=4,765 |location=South Australia |date=1 November 1938 |accessdate=22 May 2016 |page=10 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> one of the last functions to be held in the clubrooms.
The Club went into recess in December 1938<ref>{{cite news |url=http://nla.gov.au/nla.news-article131920541 |title=Holiday Plans Of Women's Societies |newspaper=[[The News (Adelaide)]] |volume=XXXI, |issue=4,803 |location=South Australia |date=15 December 1938 |accessdate=22 May 2016 |page=18 |via=National Library of Australia}}</ref> and never reopened. No public announcement was made regarding its closure either before or after.

{{more footnotes|date=June 2013}} '''Allan Robert Rosenberg''' (April 21, 1909 – April 1, 1991) was a 20th-century American attorney and civil servant, accused as a Soviet spy by [[Elizabeth Bentley]] and listed under Party name "Roy, code names "Roza" in the [[Venona project|VENONA Papers]] and code name "Sid" in the [[Alexander Vassiliev|Vasilliev Papers]].<ref> {{Cite web | first = John Earl | last = Haynes | authorlink = John Earl Haynes | title = Cover Name, Cryptonym, Pseudonym, and Real Name Index: A Research Historian’s Working Reference | publisher = John Earl Haynes | date = April 2009 | location = Washington | url = http://www.johnearlhaynes.org/page66.html | pages = | accessdate = 26 August 2017}}</ref><ref> {{cite web | first = Alexander | last = Vassiliev | authorlink = Alexander Vassiliev | title = Black Notebook | publisher = Wilson Center | date = | location = | url = http://digitalarchive.wilsoncenter.org/translations/9993.pdf | pages = 78 | accessdate = 26 August 2017}}</ref>
==Ware Group==
[[Nathan Witt]] had succeeded [[Harold Ware]] as leader of the underground [[Ware group|Ware Group]] of Soviet spies upon Ware's death in 1935, while [[Whittaker Chambers]] oversaw the group and couriered Government documents it obtained from Washington to New York.<ref name=Witness> {{Cite book | first = Whittaker | last = Chambers | authorlink = Whittaker Chambers | title = Witness | publisher = Random House | date = May 1952 | location = New York | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=WIkNAAAAIAAJ | pages = 799 (total) | lccn = 52005149}}</ref><ref name=Berle> {{Cite web | first = Adolf A. | last = Berle | authorlink = Adolf A. Berle | title = Berle Notes | publisher = John Earl Haynes | date = 2 September 1938 | location = Washington | url = http://www.johnearlhaynes.org/page100.html | pages = | accessdate = 26 August 2017}}</ref>
In 1936, Rosenberg was working "as an unpaid volunteer" for the [[Robert M. La Follette Jr.|La Follette]] [[La Follette Committee|Civil Liberties Committee]], in fact a subcommittee of the U.S. Senate Committee on Education and Labor (where Ware Group member [[John Abt]] worked); [[Charles Kramer (economist)|Charles Kramer]] and [[Charles Flato]] (another "secret communist") would join them there.<ref name=HUAC1956> {{Cite web | title = Hearings | publisher = US GPO | date = 1956 | location = Washington | url = https://archive.org/stream/investigationofc564 | pages = 3252 (Joseph Robison), 3288–3289 (David Rein), 3300–3307 (Rosenberg), 3318 (Ruth Weyand Perry), 3320 (Weyand), 3325 (Weyand), 3329 (Weyand), 3362 (Jacob Krug) | accessdate = 26 August 2017}}</ref><ref name=Ascendant> {{Cite book | first = Sean Dennis | last = Cashman | authorlink = | title = America Ascendant: From Theodore Roosevelt to FDR in the Century of American Power, 1901-1945 | publisher = NYU Press | date = 1998 | location = New York | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=TYMUCgAAQBAJ | pages = 332 | accessdate = 26 August 2017}}</ref><ref name=Secret> {{Cite book | first1 = John Earl | last1 = Haynes | authorlink1 = John Earl Haynes | first2 = Harvey | last2 = Klehr | authorlink2 = Harvey Klehr | first3 = Fridrikh | last3 = Igorevich | authorlink3 = | title = The Secret World of American Communism | publisher = Yale University Press | date = 1996 | location = New Haven | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=MBHSY0bCFWoC | pages = 98 | accessdate = 26 August 2017}}</ref>
In 1937, he transferred briefly to the [[Railroad Retirement Board]] and then in April 1937 joined the [[National Labor Relations Board]] through 1941 at the suggestion of [[Max Lowenthal]].<ref name=HUAC1952> {{cite book | title = Hearings of the United States Congress - House Committee on Un-American Activities | publisher = US GPO | page = 3435 | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=odgJAAAAIAAJ | date = 1952 | accessdate = 26 August 2017}}</ref> There, [[Charles Kramer (economist)|Charles Kramer]] joined him the following year. That same year, he also joined the [[National Lawyers Guild]] (where he was a member as a late as 1956 during his second appearance before [[HUAC]]).<ref name=HUAC1956 />
Witt placed Rosenberg in charge of a group of six to eight attorneys during a Congressional investigation into the questionable activities of the [[National Labor Relations Board]] (NRLB) in 1938 and 1939.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}}
==Perlo Group==
In 1941, Rosenberg transferred from the NRLB to the Board of Economic Warfare (or Office of Economic Warfare).<ref name=HUAC1956 />
"A couple of years later," he joined the Foreign Economic Administration (FEA).<ref name=HUAC1956 />
Rosenberg was a friend of [[Charles Kramer (economist)|Charles Kramer]] (the only member of the Ware Group known to continue on into the [[Perlo group|Perlo Group]]). Rosenberg was also an amateur photographer with a dark room in his home.<ref name=Spies> {{Cite book | first1 = John Earl | last1 = Haynes | authorlink1 = John Earl Haynes | first2 = Harvey | last2 = Klehr | authorlink2 = Harvey Klehr | first3 = Alexander | last3 = Vasilliev | authorlink3 = Alexander Vassiliev | title = Spies: The Rise and Fall of the KGB in America | publisher = Yale University Press | date = 2009 | location = New Haven | url = https://books.google.com/books?id=qCAVQ_cdomcC | pages = 276 (friendship), 284 (appearances) | accessdate = 26 August 2017}}</ref>
Rosenberg was a member of the [[Perlo group]] of Soviet spies during [[World War II]].{{citation needed|date=August 2017}}
In November 1943, [[Earl Browder]] turned control of the group over to [[Jacob Golos]] two months before his death and it subsequently was taken over by [[Elizabeth Bentley]].
While employed as the Chief of the Economic Institution Staff for the [[Foreign Economic Administration]], Rosenberg allegedly supplied the [[Soviet Union]] with voluminous observations, recommendations, plans and proposals made by various government officials concerning the handling of postwar Germany. He also worked on the [[Board of Economic Warfare]] since 1941. Rosenberg's name appears in clear text in a December 1944 Venona decrypt as the source of a [[U.S. State Department|State Department]] memo. Rosenberg appears in the [[Venona project]] under his real name.{{citation needed|date=August 2017}}
In April 1951, Rosenberg argued ''Anti-Fascist Committee v. McGrath'' before the U.S. Supreme Court.<ref> {{Cite web | title = Anti-Fascist Committee v. McGrath | publisher = Find Law | date = 30 April 1951 | location = Washington | url = https://caselaw.findlaw.com/us-supreme-court/341/123.html | pages = | accessdate = 26 August 2017}}</ref>
==Testimony==
In June 23, 1952, and again on February 21, 1956, Rosenberg testified in Congress before [[HUAC]]. Counsel in 1952 was David Scribner, counsel in 1956 Benjamin Loring Young.<ref name=HUAC1952 /><ref name=HUAC1956 /><ref name=Venona> {{Cite book | first1 = John Earl | last1 = Haynes | authorlink1 = John Earl Haynes | title = Venona: Decoding Soviet Espionage in America | publisher = Yale University Press | date = 2000 | location = New Haven | url = https://archive.org/stream/investigationofc564unit | pages = 117, 118, 119, 363, 399, 409 (fn5) (testimony), 422 (fn29) | accessdate = 26 August 2017}}</ref>
==VENONA Papers==
Rosenberg's name appears without cover in Venona but with a [[cryptonym]] in the Gorsky Memo.<ref> {{Cite web | first = John Earl | last = Haynes | authorlink = John Earl Haynes | title = Russian Archival Identification of Real Names Behind Cover Names in VENONA | publisher = John Earl Haynes | date = 27 October 2005 | location = Washington | url = http://www.johnearlhaynes.org/page59.html | pages = | accessdate = 26 August 2017}}</ref>
==See also==
* [[Ware group|Ware Group]] * [[Perlo group|Perlo Group]] * [[Venona project]] * [[National Lawyers Guild]] * [[La Follette Committee]]
==References==
{{reflist}}
==External links== *{{Citation | last = Vassiliev | first = Alexander | title = Alexander Vassiliev’s Notes on Anatoly Gorsky’s December 1948 Memo on Compromised American Sources and Networks | work = | publisher = | year = 2003 | url = http://www.wilsoncenter.org/event/alexander-vassilievs-notebooks-and-the-documentation-soviet-intelligence-operations-the-unit-0 | accessdate = 2012-04-21 }} * [http://caselaw.lp.findlaw.com/cgi-bin/getcase.pl?navby=volpage&court=us&vol=341&page=171 ''Anti-Fascist Committee v. McGrath''] (1951) Allan R. Rosenberg argued the cause before the U.S. Supreme Court. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20050730005144/http://www.nd.edu/~docctr/OMELIA/Clippings/OVERSIZE%20CLIPPINGS%20IV.htm ''2 Lawyers Balk at Query on Red Cell Affiliations: Accused by Herbert Fuchs, Ex-NLRB Employees Use 5th Amendment at House Probe''] 21 February 1956
{{PerloGroup}}

{{refimprove|date=July 2015}} {{Infobox ethnic group | group = Swedish Arabs
{{lang|ar|السويديون العرب}} | population= 210,400 (according to the [[Joshua Project]]){{cite web|url=https://joshuaproject.net/countries/SW|title=People groups: Sweden|work=Joshua Project|accessdate=24 October 2016}} | popplace = [[Stockholm]], [[Södertälje]], [[Malmö]] | langs = [[Arabic language|Arabic]], [[Swedish language|Swedish]] }} {{Contains Arabic text}} '''Swedish Arabs''' are citizens and residents of [[Sweden]] who emigrated from nations in the [[Arab world]]. ==Migration history== Many of the Arabs in Sweden are migrants from [[Syria]], [[Iraq]], [[State of Palestine|Palestine]], [[Lebanon]], [[Morocco]], [[Algeria]], [[Egypt]], [[Tunisia]], [[Libya]], [[Jordan]] and [[Yemen]]. In September 2013, Swedish migration authorities ruled that all Syrian asylum seekers will be granted permanent residency in light of [[Syrian Civil War|the worsening conflict in Syria]]. [[Sweden]] is the first [[Member state of the European Union|EU-country]] to make this offer.{{cite web|title=Sweden offers residency to all Syrian refugees |url=http://www.thelocal.se/50030/20130903/ |publisher=[[The Local]] |accessdate=3 September 2013 |date=3 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130904224518/http://www.thelocal.se/50030/20130903/ |archivedate=4 September 2013 |df=dmy }} The decision means that the roughly 8,000 Syrians who have [[temporary residency]] in Sweden will now be able to stay in the country permanently. They will also have the right to bring their families to Sweden. While Malek Laesker, vice-chair of the Syrian Arabian Cultural Association of Sweden, welcomed the decision, he also warned it could create problems. "The fact that Sweden is the first country to open its arms is both positive and negative," he told the [[Tidningarnas Telegrambyrå|TT news agency]], explaining that it may be a boon for the growing [[people-smuggling]] market. ==Notable people== ;Film, television and acting * [[Malik Bendjelloul]], filmmaker of Algerian descent * [[Mohamed Said (actor)]], actor of Iraqi origin * [[Tarik Saleh]], film director of Egyptian descent * [[Said Legue]], actor and script writer of Moroccan origin ;Musicians and singers * [[Salem Al Fakir]], Grammy Award winning singer of Syrian origin * [[Rabih Jaber]], singer of Lebanese origin, also part of [[Rebound!]] with Eddie Razaz * [[Josef Johansson]], pop singer of Tunisian origin * [[Leila K]], singer and rapper of Moroccan descent * [[Maher Zain]], singer and songwriter of Lebanese origin * [[RedOne]], songwriter of Moroccan origin ;Sports * [[Nabil Bahoui]], footballer of Moroccan origin * [[Nadir Benchenaa]], footballer of Algerian origin * [[Dalil Benyahia]], footballer of Algerian descent * [[Louay Chanko]], footballer of Syrian origin * [[Jimmy Durmaz]], footballer of Syrian-Turkish origin * [[Seif Kadhim]], football of Iraqi origin * [[Mohammed Ali Khan]], footballer of Lebanese origin * [[George Moussan]], footballer of Syrian origin * [[Christer Youssef]], footballer of Syrian origin ;Others * [[Modhir Ahmed]], visual artist of Iraqi origin * [[Mahmoud Aldebe]], of the Muslim association of Jordanian descent * [[Nadia Jebril]], journalist and TV host Palestinian origin * [[Osama Krayem]], suspected terrorist of Palestinian origin * [[Fida al-Sayed]], political activist of Syrian descent ==References== {{reflist}} == External source == * [http://www.government.se/ Dialogue and openness - Sweden in the UN Security Council] ==See also == *[[Arab diaspora]] *[[Arabs in Europe]] *[[Islam in Sweden]] *[[Moroccans in Sweden]] *[[Iraqis in Sweden]] *[[Lebanese people in Sweden]] *[[Syrians in Sweden]] *[[Immigration to Sweden]] {{Immigration to Sweden}} {{Arab diaspora}} [[Category:Arabs in Sweden| ]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Sweden]] [[Category:Swedish people of Arab descent]] [[Category:Middle Eastern diaspora in Sweden]] [[Category:Muslim communities in Europe]] {{Asia-ethno-group-stub}} {{Africa-ethno-group-stub}}

{{short description|The sea ice loss observed in recent decades in the Arctic Ocean}} {{multiple image | width1 = 184 | footer = <center>Satellite views of Arctic sea ice.</center> | image1 = Mosaic of the Arctic.jpg | alt1 = September 2, 2012, the record lowest minimum ever observed in the satellite record. | caption1 = September 2, 2012 — two weeks later, the record lowest minimum occurred: {{convert|3,410,000|sqkm|sqmi}} | width2 = 216 | image2 = Arctic Sea Ice from January 1, 2013 to September 10, 2016.webm | alt2 = January 1, 2013 through September 10, 2016, when the sea ice reached its annual minimum extent. | caption2 = January 1, 2013 through September 10, 2016, the latter date being when the sea ice reached its annual minimum extent }} {{multiple image | width = 200 | footer = <center>Every year, Arctic sea ice grows and extends through the winter. On March 7, 2017, Arctic sea ice reached its record lowest maximum.</center> | alt1 = | caption1 = | image2 = Arctic SeaIce.gif | alt2 = | caption2 = }} [[File:Arctic sea ice reaches lowest maximum extent on record.png|thumb|Arctic sea ice extent as of February 3, 2016. January Arctic sea ice extent was the lowest in the satellite record. credit: [http://nsidc.org/arcticseaicenews/2016/02/january-hits-new-record-low-in-the-arctic/ NSIDC].]] [[File:Sea ice 1953-2016.png|thumb|Arctic sea ice extent anomaly.]] [[File:Disappearing Ice.webm|thumb|This video shows how the quantity of older and thicker ice has changed between 1984 and 2016.]]
'''Arctic sea ice decline''' is the [[sea ice]] loss observed in recent decades in the [[Arctic Ocean]]. The [[IPCC Fourth Assessment Report|Intergovernmental Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) Fourth Assessment Report]] states that [[Radiative forcing#Forcing due to atmospheric gas|greenhouse gas forcing]] is largely, but not wholly, responsible for the decline in Arctic sea ice extent. A study from 2011 suggested that internal variability enhanced the greenhouse gas forced sea ice decline over the last decades.<ref>{{cite journal |title=Inter-annual to multi-decadal Arctic sea ice extent trends in a warming world|date= August 22, 2011|doi=10.1029/2011GL048008|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|authors=Jennifer E. Kay, Marika M. Holland & Alexandra Jahn|bibcode=2011GeoRL..3815708K|volume=38|issue= 15|pages= L15708}}</ref> A study from 2007 found the decline to be "faster than forecasted" by model simulations.<ref name="ReferenceA">{{Cite journal| first1 = J.| last2 = Holland| first2 = M. M.| last4 = Scambos| last3 = Meier| last5 = Serreze | first3 = W.| last1 = Stroeve| first4 = T.| first5 = M.| title = Arctic sea ice decline: Faster than forecast| journal = Geophysical Research Letters| volume = 34| issue = 9| pages = L09501| year = 2007| doi = 10.1029/2007GL029703| bibcode=2007GeoRL..3409501S}}</ref> The [[IPCC Fifth Assessment Report]] concluded with high confidence that sea ice continues to decrease in extent, and that there is robust evidence for the downward trend in Arctic summer sea ice extent since 1979.<ref name="AR5">{{cite journal | title = The Physical Science Basis | year = 2013 | url=http://www.ipcc.ch/meetings/session36/p36_doc3_approved_spm.pdf | author = IPCC AR5 WG1 }}</ref> It has been established that the region is at its warmest for at least 40,000 years and the Arctic-wide melt season has lengthened at a rate of 5 days per decade (from 1979 to 2013), dominated by a later autumn freezeup.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Changes in Arctic melt season and implications for sea ice loss | year = 2014 |author1=J. C. Stroeve |author2=T. Markus |author3=L. Boisvert |author4=J. Miller |author5=A. Barrett | doi=10.1002/2013GL058951|bibcode = 2014GeoRL..41.1216S | volume=41 | issue = 4 | journal=Geophysical Research Letters | pages=1216–1225}}</ref> Sea ice changes have been identified as a mechanism for [[polar amplification]].<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kwang-Yul Kim1, Benjamin D. Hamlington2, Hanna Na3, and Jinju Kim1|year=|title=Mechanism of seasonal Arctic sea ice evolution and Arctic amplification|url=|journal=The Cryosphere|volume=|pages=|via=}}</ref>
==Definitions== The [[Arctic Ocean]] is the mass of water positioned approximately above latitude 65° N. [[Arctic ice pack|Arctic Sea Ice]] refers to the area of the Arctic Ocean covered in ice. The ''Arctic sea ice minimum'' is the day in a given year when Arctic sea ice reaches its smallest extent. It occurs at the end of the summer melting season, normally during September. ''Arctic Sea ice maximum'' is the day of a year when Arctic sea ice reaches its largest extent near the end of the Arctic cold season, normally during March.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nsidc.org/cryosphere/quickfacts/seaice.html|title=Quick Facts on Arctic Sea Ice|author=NSIDC|accessdate=15 May 2015}}</ref> Typical data visualizations for Arctic sea ice include average monthly measurements or graphs for the annual minimum or maximum extent, as shown in the adjacent images.
==Observation== {{main|Measurement of sea ice}} [[File:Annual Arctic Sea Ice Minimum 1979-2015 with Area Graph.webm|thumb|An animation of the annual Arctic sea ice minimum with a graph overlay showing the area of the minimum sea ice in millions of square kilometres.]] An article in [[Popular Mechanics]], published in March 1912, described open waters in the Arctic regions in 1911, a year with exceptional above average temperatures.<ref>{{cite book|url=https://archive.org/stream/PopularMechanics1912/Popular_Mechanics_03_1912#page/n85/mode/2up|publisher=Popular Mechanics|author=Francis Molena|year=1912|title=Remarkable Weather of 1911}}</ref>
===Satellite era=== [[File:2018 Sea Ice Extent Visualization.gif|thumb|2018 sea ice extent visualization.]] Observation with satellites show that Arctic sea ice area, extent, and volume have been in decline for a few decades. Sometime during the 21st century, sea ice may effectively cease to exist during the summer. Sea ice extent is defined as the area with at least 15% ice cover.<ref>{{cite web|title=Daily Updated Time series of Arctic sea ice area and extent derived from SSMI data provided by NERSC |url=http://arctic-roos.org/observations/satellite-data/sea-ice/ |accessdate=14 September 2013 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20130910091853/http://arctic-roos.org/observations/satellite-data/sea-ice |archivedate=10 September 2013 }}</ref> The amount of multi-year sea ice in the Arctic has declined considerably in recent decades. In 1988, ice that was at least 4 years old accounted for 26% of the Arctic's sea ice. By 2013, ice that age was only 7% of all Arctic sea ice.<ref>[https://www.theguardian.com/environment/2014/feb/21/arctic-ice-melt-video Watch 27 years of 'old' Arctic ice melt away in seconds] The Guardian 21 February 2014</ref>
Scientists recently measured sixteen-foot (five-meter) [[wave heights]] during a storm in the [[Beaufort Sea]] in mid-August until late October 2012. This is a new phenomenon for the region, since a permanent sea ice cover normally prevents wave formation. Wave action breaks up sea ice, and thus could become a feedback mechanism, driving sea ice decline.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.washington.edu/news/2014/07/29/huge-waves-measured-for-first-time-in-arctic-ocean/|title=Huge waves measured for first time in Arctic Ocean|date=July 29, 2014|author=Hannah Hickey|publisher=[[University of Washington]]}}</ref>
For January 2016, the satellite based data showed the lowest overall Arctic sea ice extent of any January since records begun in 1979. Bob Henson from Wunderground noted: {{quote|Hand in hand with the skimpy ice cover, temperatures across the Arctic have been extraordinarily warm for midwinter. Just before New Year’s, a slug of mild air pushed temperatures above freezing to within 200 miles of the North Pole. That warm pulse quickly dissipated, but it was followed by a series of intense North Atlantic cyclones that sent very mild air poleward, in tandem with a strongly negative [[Arctic oscillation]] during the first three weeks of the month.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wunderground.com/blog/JeffMasters/absurd-january-warmth-in-arctic-brings-recordlow-sea-ice-extent|title=Absurd January Warmth in Arctic Brings Record-Low Sea Ice Extent|year=2016|publisher=Wunderground}}</ref>}}
The January 2016's remarkable phase transition of Arctic oscillation was driven by a [http://onlinelibrary.wiley.com/doi/10.1002/2017GL073012/abstract rapid tropospheric warming in the Arctic], a pattern that appears to have increased surpassing the so-called stratospheric sudden warming.<ref>Wang, S.-Y. S., Y.-H. Lin, M.-Y. Lee, J.-H. Yoon, J. D. D. Meyer, and P. J. Rasch (2017), Accelerated increase in the Arctic tropospheric warming events surpassing stratospheric warming events during winter, Geophys. Res. Lett., 44, doi:10.1002/2017GL073012.</ref> The previous record of the lowest area of the Arctic Ocean covered by ice in 2012 saw a low of 1.58 million square miles (4.1 million square kilometers). This replaced the previous record set on September 28, 2007 at 1.61 million square miles(4.17 million square kilometers).<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://news.nationalgeographic.com/news/2012/08/120828-arctic-sea-ice-global-warming-record-environment-science/?source=arctichub|title=Arctic Sea Ice Hits Record Low—Extreme Weather to Come?|date=2016-08-29|access-date=2016-11-29}}</ref>
==Ice-free summer== [[File:NORTH POLE Ice (19626661335).jpg|thumb|The dark ocean surface reflects only 6 percent of incoming solar radiation, instead sea ice reflects 50 to 70 percent.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nsidc.org/cryosphere/seaice/processes/albedo.html|title=Thermodynamics: Albedo|work=NSIDC}}</ref>]] [[File:Ponds on the Ocean, ICESCAPE.jpg|thumb|left|As ice melts, the liquid water collects in depressions on the surface and deepens them, forming these melt ponds in the [[Arctic]]. These fresh water ponds are separated from the salty sea below and around it, until breaks in the ice merge the two.]]
An "ice-free" Arctic Ocean is often defined as "having less than 1 million square kilometers of sea ice", because it is very difficult to melt the thick ice around the [[Canadian Arctic Archipelago]].<ref>http://www.pnas.org/content/early/2013/07/10/1219716110.abstract [[PNAS]]</ref><ref>{{Cite web | url=http://phys.org/news/2013-08-ice-free-arctic-2050s.html#inlRlv | title=Study predicts an ice-free Arctic by the 2050s}}</ref><ref>http://www.atmos.pku.edu.cn/yhu/pnas-liu-2013.pdf</ref> The IPCC AR5 defines "nearly ice-free conditions" as sea ice extent less than 10<sup>6</sup> km<sup>2</sup> for at least five consecutive years.<ref name="AR5" />
Many scientists have attempted to estimate when the Arctic will be "ice-free". Professor [[Peter Wadhams]] of the University of Cambridge is among these scientists.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=8xdOTyGQOso&feature=youtu.be|title=Our time is running out – The Arctic sea ice is going!|last=Wadhams|first=Peter|date=20 June 2015|website=www.youtube.com|publisher=|access-date=29 November 2016}}</ref> Wadhams and several others have noted that climate model predictions have been overly conservative regarding sea ice decline.<ref name="ReferenceA"/><ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Overland | first1 = J. E. | last2 = Wang | first2 = M. | doi = 10.1002/grl.50316 | title = When will the summer Arctic be nearly sea ice free? | journal = Geophysical Research Letters | volume = 40 | issue = 10 | pages = 2097 | year = 2013 | pmid = | pmc = |bibcode = 2013GeoRL..40.2097O }}</ref> A 2013 paper suggested that models commonly underestimate the solar radiation absorption characteristics of wildfire soot.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=China|first1=Swarup|last2=Claudio|first2=Mazzoleni|last3=Gorkowski|first3=Kyle|last4=Aiken|first4=Allison|last5=Dubey|first5=Manvendra|title=Morphology and mixing state of individual freshly emitted wildfire carbonaceous particles|journal=Nat. Commun.|date=2013|doi=10.1038/ncomms3122|pmid=23824042|pmc=3715871|url=http://www.nature.com/ncomms/2013/130704/ncomms3122/full/ncomms3122.html|bibcode = 2013NatCo...4E2122C|volume=4|pages=2122}}</ref> A 2006 paper predicted "near ice-free September conditions by 2040".<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Holland | first1 = M. M. | last2 = Bitz | first2 = C. M. | last3 = Tremblay | first3 = B. | title = Future abrupt reductions in the summer Arctic sea ice | doi = 10.1029/2006GL028024 | journal = Geophysical Research Letters | volume = 33 | issue = 23 | pages = L23503 | year = 2006 | pmid = | pmc = |bibcode = 2006GeoRL..3323503H }}</ref>''Overland and Wang'' (2013) investigated three different ways of predicting future sea ice levels. From sea ice models and recent satellite images it can be expected that a sea ice free summer will come before 2020.<ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Overland|first=James E.|date=21 May 2013|title=When will the summer Arctic be nearly sea ice free?|url=|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|volume=40|issue=10|pages=2097–2101|via=|doi=10.1002/grl.50316|bibcode=2013GeoRL..40.2097O}}</ref> The IPCC AR5 (for at least one scenario) estimates an ice-free summer might occur around 2050.<ref name="AR5" /> The Third U.S. [[National Climate Assessment]] (NCA), released May 6, 2014, reports that the [[Arctic Ocean]] is expected to be ice free in summer before mid-century. Models that best match historical trends project a nearly ice-free Arctic in the summer by the 2030s.<ref name="Melting Ice">{{cite web|title=Melting Ice Key Message Third National Climate Assessment|url=http://nca2014.globalchange.gov/report/our-changing-climate/melting-ice|website=National Climate Assessment|accessdate=25 June 2014}}</ref> However, these models do tend to underestimate the rate of sea ice loss since 2007. Based on the outcomes of several different models, ''Overland and Wang'' (2013) putthe early limit for a sea ice free summer Arctic near 2040.<ref name=":1" />
[[File:Arctic-death-spiral.png|thumb|Monthly averages from 1979 - 2017. Data source via the [http://psc.apl.washington.edu/ Polar Science Center] ([[University of Washington]]). Data visualisation by [http://haveland.com Andy Lee Robinson].]]
Warming Arctic temperatures provide a powerful forcing toward lessened sea ice coverage<ref>Comiso, J.C., Parkinson, C.L., Gersten, R. and Stock, L., 2008. Accelerated decline in the Arctic sea ice. Geophysical research letters, 35(1).</ref>
==Tipping point== There is an ongoing debate if the Arctic Ocean has already passed a "tipping point", defined as a threshold for abrupt and irreversible change. A 2013 study identified an abrupt transition to increased seasonal ice cover variability in 2007, which has persisted in following years. The researchers made a distinction between a [[Bifurcation theory|bifurcation]] and a non-bifurcation `tipping point'.<ref>{{cite journal|title=A recent tipping point in the Arctic sea-ice cover: abrupt and persistent increase in the seasonal cycle since 2007|year=2013|authors=Valerie N. Livina, Timothy M. Lenton|doi=10.5194/tc-7-275-2013|arxiv=1204.5445|bibcode = 2013TCry....7..275L|volume=7|issue=1|journal=The Cryosphere|pages=275–286}}</ref> The ''IPCC AR5'' report stated with medium confidence that precise levels of climate change sufficient to trigger a tipping point remain uncertain, and that the risk associated with crossing multiple tippingpoints increases with rising temperature.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WG2AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf |title=Climate change 2014, Impacts, Adaptation and Vulnerability |year=2014 |author=IPCC AR5 WGII |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20150514034430/http://ipcc-wg2.gov/AR5/images/uploads/WG2AR5_SPM_FINAL.pdf |archivedate=2015-05-14 }}</ref>
==Implications== [[File:Map of the Arctic region showing the Northeast Passage, the Northern Sea Route and Northwest Passage, and bathymetry.png|thumb|Map illustrating various Arctic shipping routes]] {{See also|Climate change feedback}}
=== Amplified Arctic Warming === Dark, open water left behind as sea ice melts absorbs vastly more heat than ice covered water, leading to physical implications that include the [[ice-albedo feedback]] or warmer sea surface temperatures which increase [[ocean heat content]]. As Peter Wadhams, a polar researcher writes "once summer ice yields to open water, the albedo... drops from 0.6 to 0.1, which will further accelerate warming of the Arctic and of the whole planet."<ref>{{Cite book|title=A Farewell To Ice|last=Wadhams|first=Peter|publisher=Penguin|year=2016|isbn=9780241009413|location=UK|pages=4|quote=|via=}}</ref> This warming has increased to such an extent that the poles are heating approximately twice as fast as the global average, according to Rutgers University climate scientist Jennifer Francis<ref name=":2">{{Cite news|url=https://insideclimatenews.org/news/02022018/cold-weather-polar-vortex-jet-stream-explained-global-warming-arctic-ice-climate-change|title=Polar Vortex: How the Jet Stream and Climate Change Bring on Cold Snaps|date=2018-02-02|work=InsideClimate News|access-date=2018-11-24|language=en}}</ref>. Economical implications of ice free summers and the decline in Arctic ice volumes include a greater number of journeys across the Arctic Ocean Shipping lanes during the year. This number has grown from 0, in 1979 to 400–500 along the [[Bering Strait|Bering strait]] and >40 along the [[Northern Sea Route]], in 2013.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://environment.nationalgeographic.com/environment/energy/great-energy-challenge/arctic-map/?source=arctichub|title=Interactive Map: The Changing Arctic|last=Society|first=National Geographic|newspaper=National Geographic|access-date=2016-11-29}}</ref>
=== Polar Vortex Disruption === The [[polar vortex]] is a whirlwind of especially cold, dense air forming near the poles that is contained by the [[jet stream]], a belt of fast-flowing winds that serves as a boundary between cold polar air and the warmer air of other hemispheres. Because the power of the polar vortex and jet stream is derived partly from the temperature contrast between cold polar air and warmer tropical air, it is at risk of becoming severely diminished as this contrast is eroded by the effects of melting sea ice.<ref name=":2" /> According to the [[Journal of the Atmospheric Sciences]] ”there [has been] a significant change in the vortex mean state over the twenty-first century, resulting in a weaker, more disturbed vortex."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Mitchell|first=Daniel M.|last2=Osprey|first2=Scott M.|last3=Gray|first3=Lesley J.|last4=Butchart|first4=Neal|last5=Hardiman|first5=Steven C.|last6=Charlton-Perez|first6=Andrew J.|last7=Watson|first7=Peter|date=August 2012|title=The Effect of Climate Change on the Variability of the Northern Hemisphere Stratospheric Polar Vortex|journal=Journal of the Atmospheric Sciences|language=en|volume=69|issue=8|pages=2608–2618|doi=10.1175/jas-d-12-021.1|issn=0022-4928}}</ref> As the vortex becomes weaker, it is more likely to allow cold arctic air to escape from the confines of the jet stream and spill over into other hemispheres.<ref name=":2" /> This disruption has already begun to affect global temperatures. In a 2017 study conducted by climatologist Dr. Judah Cohen and several of his research associates, Cohen wrote that “[the] shift in polar vortex states can account for ''most'' of the recent winter cooling trends over Eurasian midlatitudes”<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Kretschmer|first=Marlene|last2=Coumou|first2=Dim|last3=Agel|first3=Laurie|last4=Barlow|first4=Mathew|last5=Tziperman|first5=Eli|last6=Cohen|first6=Judah|date=January 2018|title=More-Persistent Weak Stratospheric Polar Vortex States Linked to Cold Extremes|journal=Bulletin of the American Meteorological Society|language=en|volume=99|issue=1|pages=49–60|doi=10.1175/bams-d-16-0259.1|issn=0003-0007}}</ref>
=== Atmospheric chemistry === {{See also|Arctic methane release}} Melting of sea ice releases molecular [[chlorine]], which reacts with sunlight to produce chlorine atoms. Because chlorine atoms are highly reactive, they can expedite the degradation of [[Atmospheric methane|methane]] and [[tropospheric ozone]] and the oxidation of [[Mercury (element)|mercury]] to more toxic forms.<ref>{{cite journal | author = Jin Liao et al.(2013) |date=January 2014 | title = High levels of molecular chlorine in the Arctic atmosphere | journal = Nature Geoscience | volume = 7 | issue = 2 | pages = 91–94 | bibcode = 2014NatGe...7...91L | doi = 10.1038/ngeo2046 | pmid = | id = | url = http://www.nature.com/ngeo/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/ngeo2046.html | accessdate = January 14, 2014 | language = }}</ref> Cracks in sea ice are causing ozone and mercury uptake in the surrounding environment.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Christopher W. Moore |author2=Daniel Obrist |author3=Alexandra Steffen |author4=Ralf M. Staebler |author5=Thomas A. Douglas |author6=Andreas Richter |author7=Son V. Nghiem |date=January 2014 | title = Convective forcing of mercury and ozone in the Arctic boundary layer induced by leads in sea ice | journal = Nature Letters | volume = 506 | issue = 7486 | pages = 81–84 | bibcode = 2014Natur.506...81M | doi = 10.1038/nature12924 | pmid =24429521 | id = | url = http://www.nature.com/nature/journal/vaop/ncurrent/full/nature12924.html | accessdate = January 16, 2014 | language = }}</ref>
A 2015 study concluded that Arctic sea ice decline accelerates [[methane emissions]] from the Arctic tundra. One of the study researchers noted, "The expectation is that with further sea ice decline, temperatures in the Arctic will continue to rise, and so will [[atmospheric methane|methane]] emissions from northern wetlands."<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.sciencedaily.com/releases/2015/09/150917091306.htm|publisher=ScienceDaily|year=2015|title=Melting Arctic sea ice accelerates methane emissions}}</ref>
=== Atmospheric regime === {{See also|Polar amplification}} [[File:Influence of Arctic sea ice on European summer pre.ogv|thumb|left|Influence of Arctic sea ice on European summer precipitation.]]
A link has been proposed between reduced Barents-Kara sea ice and cold winter extremes over northern continents.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Vladimir Petoukhov |author2=Vladimir A. Semenov |date=November 2010 | title = A link between reduced Barents-Kara sea ice and cold winter extremes over northern continents | journal = Journal of Geophysical Research: Atmospheres | volume = 115 | issue = 21 | pages = D21111 | bibcode =2010JGRD..11521111P | doi = 10.1029/2009JD013568 | pmid = | id = | language = }}</ref> Model simulation suggest diminished Arctic sea ice may have been a contributing driver of recent wet summers over northern Europe, because of a weakened [[jet stream]], which dives further south.<ref name="Screen 2013">{{cite journal | author = J A Screen |date=November 2013 | title = Influence of Arctic sea ice on European summer precipitation | journal = Environmental Research Letters | volume = 8 | issue = 4 | page = 044015 | bibcode = 2013ERL.....8d4015S | doi = 10.1088/1748-9326/8/4/044015 | pmid = | id = | url = http://iopscience.iop.org/1748-9326/8/4/044015 | format = | accessdate = January 26, 2014 | language = }}</ref> Extreme summer weather in northern mid-latitudes has been linked to a vanishing [[cryosphere]].<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Qiuhong Tang |author2=Xuejun Zhang |author3=Jennifer A. Francis |date=December 2013 | title = Extreme summer weather in northern mid-latitudes linked to a vanishing cryosphere | journal = Nature Climate Change | volume = 4 | issue = 1 | pages = 45–50 | bibcode = 2014NatCC...4...45T | doi = 10.1038/nclimate2065 | pmid = | id = | url = http://iopscience.iop.org/1748-9326/8/4/044015 | format = | accessdate = January 26, 2014 | language = }}</ref> Evidence suggest that the continued loss of Arctic sea-ice and snow cover may influence weather at lower latitudes. Correlations have been identified between high-latitude cryosphere changes, hemispheric wind patterns and mid-latitude extreme weather events for the Northern Hemisphere.<ref>{{cite journal | author = James E. Overland |date=December 2013 | title = Atmospheric science: Long-range linkage | journal = Nature Climate Change | volume = 4 | issue = 1 | pages = 11–12 | bibcode = 2014NatCC...4...11O | doi = 10.1038/nclimate2079 | pmid = | id = | url = http://www.nature.com/nclimate/journal/v4/n1/full/nclimate2079.html | accessdate = January 26, 2014 | language = }}</ref> A study from 2004, connected the disappearing sea ice with a reduction of available water in the American west.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Geophysical Research Letters|year=2004|title=Disappearing Arctic sea ice reduces available water in the American west|doi=10.1029/2003GL019133|authors=Jacob O. Sewall, Lisa Cirbus Sloan|bibcode=2004GeoRL..31.6209S|volume=31|issue=6|pages=L06209}}</ref>
Based on effects of Arctic amplification (warming) and ice loss, a study in 2015 concluded that highly amplified jet-stream patterns are occurring more frequently in the past two decades, and that such patterns can not be tied to certain seasons. Additionally it was found that these jet-stream patterns often lead to persistent weather patterns that result in extreme weather events. Hence, continued heat trapping emissions favour increased formation of extreme events caused by prolonged weather conditions.<ref>{{cite journal|journal=Philosophical Transactions|title=Evidence linking rapid Arctic warming to mid-latitude weather patterns|url=http://rsta.royalsocietypublishing.org/content/373/2045/20140170|doi=10.1098/rsta.2014.0170|pmid=26032322|authors=Jennifer Francis, Natasa Skific|date=1 June 2015|bibcode = 2015RSPTA.37340170F|volume=373|issue=2045|page=20140170|pmc=4455715}}</ref>
In 2018, climate scientist [[Michael E. Mann]] explained that the west Antarctic ice sheet may lose twice as much ice by the end of the century as previously thought, which also doubles the projected rise in sea level from three feet to more than six feet.<ref>{{cite web |last1=Mann |first1=Michael E.|authorlink=Michael E. Mann |title=Climate Scientist Won't Back Down Despite Threats, Harassment |url=https://www.kqed.org/science/1923414/why-this-climate-scientist-is-optimistic-despite-record-co2-levels |website=KQED Science |publisher=KQED |accessdate=27 November 2018|date=2018-05-07}}</ref>
[[File:Average September Arctic Sea Ice Comparison 1979 vs 2013.ogg|thumb|This animation shows the difference in the area, volume and depth of the average September Arctic sea ice between 1979 and 2013.]]
=== Plant and animal life === {{see also|Polar bear#Climate change}}
Sea ice decline has been linked to [[boreal forest]] decline in North America and is assumed to culminate with an intensifying wildfire regime in this region.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Martin P. Girardin |author2=Xiao Jing Guo |author3=Rogier De Jong |author4=Christophe Kinnard |author5=Pierre Bernier |author6=Frédéric Raulier |date=December 2013 | title = Unusual forest growth decline in boreal North America covaries with the retreat of Arctic sea ice | journal = Global Change Biology | volume = 20 | issue = 3 | pages = 851–866 | bibcode =2014GCBio..20..851G | doi = 10.1111/gcb.12400 | pmid =24115302 | id = | language = }}</ref> The annual net primary production of the Eastern Bering Sea was enhanced by 40–50% through phytoplankton blooms during warm years of early sea ice retreat.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Zachary W. Brown |author2=Kevin R. Arrigo |date=January 2013 | title = Sea ice impacts on spring bloom dynamics and net primary production in the Eastern Bering Sea | journal = Journal of Geophysical Research: Oceans | volume = 118 | issue = 1 | pages = 43–62 | bibcode =2013JGRC..118...43B | doi = 10.1029/2012JC008034 | pmid = | id = | language = }}</ref>
Polar bears are turning to alternate food sources because Arctic sea ice melts earlier and freezes later each year. As a result, they have less time to hunt their historically preferred prey of seal pups, and must spend more time on land and hunt other animals.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Elizabeth Peacock |author2=Mitchell K. Taylor |author3=Jeffrey Laake |author4=Ian Stirling |date=April 2013 | title = Population ecology of polar bears in Davis Strait, Canada and Greenland | journal = The Journal of Wildlife Management | volume = 77 | issue = 3 | pages = 463–476 | bibcode = | doi = 10.1002/jwmg.489 | pmid = | id = | language = }}</ref> As a result, the diet is less nutritional, which leads to reduced body size and reproduction, thus indicating population decline in polar bears.<ref>{{cite journal |author1=Karyn D. Rode |author2=Steven C. Amstrup |author3=Eric V. Regehr | year = 2010 | month = | title = Reduced body size and cub recruitment in polar bears associated with sea ice decline | journal = Ecological Applications | volume = 20 | issue = 3 | pages = 768–782 | bibcode = | doi = 10.1890/08-1036.1 | pmid = | id = | language = }}</ref>
=== Shipping === [[Global warming in the Arctic|Melting Arctic ice caps]] are likely to increase traffic through the Arctic Ocean.<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/07/23/climate/ships-in-the-arctic.html|title=With More Ships in the Arctic, Fears of Disaster Rise|last=Fountain|first=Henry|date=2017-07-23|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-07-24|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref><ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/science-environment-41037071|title=First tanker crosses northern sea route without ice breaker|last=McGrath|first=Matt|date=2017-08-24|work=BBC News|access-date=2017-08-24|language=en-GB}}</ref> An early study by [[James Hansen]] and colleagues suggested in 1981 that warming of 5 to 10 °C, which they expected as the range of Arctic temperature change corresponding to doubled {{co2}} concentrations, could open the [[Northwest Passage]].<ref>{{cite journal | author = Hansen, J.|year=1981|title=Climate impact of increasing atmospheric carbon dioxide|url=https://pubs.giss.nasa.gov/abs/ha04600x.html|journal=Science|volume=231|issue=4511|pages=957–966|doi=10.1126/science.213.4511.957|pmid=17789014|display-authors=etal|bibcode=1981Sci...213..957H}}</ref> A 2016 study concludes that Arctic warming and sea ice decline will lead to "remarkable shifts in trade flows between Asia and Europe, diversion of trade within Europe, heavy shipping traffic in the Arctic and a substantial drop in Suez traffic. Projected shifts in trade also imply substantial pressure on an already threatened Arctic ecosystem."<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Bekkers|first=Eddy|last2=Francois|first2=Joseph F.|last3=Rojas-Romagosa|first3=Hugo|date=2016-12-01|title=Melting Ice Caps and the Economic Impact of Opening the Northern Sea Route|journal=The Economic Journal|volume=128|issue=610|language=en|pages=1095–1127|doi=10.1111/ecoj.12460|issn=1468-0297}}</ref> In August 2017, the first ship traversed the Northern Sea Route without the use of ice-breakers.<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=https://www.nytimes.com/2017/08/25/world/europe/russia-tanker-christophe-de-margerie.html|title=Russian Tanker Completes Arctic Passage Without Aid of Icebreakers|last=Goldman|first=Russell|date=2017-08-25|work=The New York Times|access-date=2017-08-26|language=en-US|issn=0362-4331}}</ref> Also in 2017, the Finnish icebreaker [[MSV Nordica]], set a record for the earliest crossing of the Northwest Passage.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.independent.co.uk/news/world/americas/northwest-passage-record-arctic-nordica-canada-greenland-melting-ice-a7868116.html|title=Ship sets record for earliest crossing of notorious Northwest Passage through Arctic|date=July 30, 2017|work=The Independent}}</ref> According to the ''New York Times'', this forebodes more shipping through the Arctic, as the sea ice melts and makes shipping easier.<ref name=":0" /> A 2016 report by the Copenhagen Business School found that large-scale trans-Arctic shipping will become economically viable by 2040.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://services-webdav.cbs.dk/doc/CBS.dk/Arctic%20Shipping%20-%20Commercial%20Opportunities%20and%20Challenges.pdf|title=Arctic shipping - Commercial opportunities and challenges|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref><ref name=":0" />{{Clear}}

{{infobox ethnic group |group= Bulgarians in Serbia
Бугари у Србији
Българи в Сърбия |image = Flag of bulgarian national minority in Serbia.gif |image_caption = Flag of the National Council of the Bulgarian Minority in Serbia |pop= '''18,543''' (2011){{cite web|url=http://popis2011.stat.rs/?lang=en|title=Serbian 2011 census}} |popplace= [[Bosilegrad]], [[Dimitrovgrad, Serbia|Dimitrovgrad]]{{cite web|url=http://www.stat.gov.rs/zip/esn31.pdf|title=Serbian 2002 census|publisher=|accessdate=2008-04-18}} |rels=[[Bulgarian Orthodox Church|Bulgarian Orthodox]] and [[Serbian Orthodox Church|Serbian Orthodox]] |langs=[[Bulgarian language|Bulgarian]], [[Serbian language|Serbian]] |footnotes= }} '''Bulgarians''' are a recognized national minority in [[Serbia]]. ==Demographics== Censuses:{{cite web|url=http://pod2.stat.gov.rs/ObjavljenePublikacije/Popis2011/Etnomozaik.pdf |title=Ethno-confessional and language mosaic of Serbia |publisher=Statistical Office of the Republic of Serbia |year=2014}}{{cite web|url=http://www.isac-fund.org/download/sr-bg-BUG.pdf}} * 1948: 59,472 * 1953: 60,146 (Bulgarian mother tongue: 59,166) * 1961: 58,494 * 1971: 53,800 (Bulgarian mother tongue: 49,942) * 1981: 33,455 (Bulgarian mother tongue: 35,269) * 1991: 26,698 (Bulgarian mother tongue: 25,408) * 2002: 20,497 (Bulgarian mother tongue: 16,459) * 2011: 18,543 (Bulgarian mother tongue: 13,337) According to the 2011 census, there were 18,543 Bulgarians in Serbia. They are primarily located in two municipalities near Serbia's border with Bulgaria: in [[Bosilegrad]] there are 5,839 Bulgarians i.e. 71.9% of population while in [[Dimitrovgrad, Serbia|Dimitrovgrad]] (Tsaribrod) there are 5,413 Bulgarians or 53.5% of population. The dominant religion among ethnic Bulgarians in Serbia is [[Eastern Orthodox|Orthodoxy]]. [[Islam]] never arrived in areas like [[Bosilegrad]] because of the mountainous terrain and most inhabitants dwelled in high mountain villages where they were hard to reach. They use both [[Serbian Orthodox church|Serbian]] and [[Bulgarian Orthodox Church|Bulgarian]] churches due to the low number of Bulgarian clergymen present in the region. There is a church in every village around [[Bosilegrad]], and the oldest ones date to the 11th century. ==History== [[File:Vasil Levski Bosilegrad.jpg|thumb|left|Unveiling of the monument of Bulgarian revolutionary [[Vasil Levski]] in [[Bosilegrad]]]] [[File:Desjardins Balkans 1853.jpg|thumb|Ethnological map by Professor Constant Desjardins (1787‒1876). This map bears the title „Serbia and the districts in which Serbian language is spoken". It was issued in Belgrade in 1853. The author states that his map had been put together according to Serbian authors.]] {{see also|Torlaks|Shopi}} {{Bulgarians}} The regional names once used by many people in the Torlakian-speaking region was ''Torlaci'' and ''Šopi'' speaking a transitional speech between Bulgarian and Serbian. The borders of the region frequently shifted before the [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] conquest among [[Byzantine Empire|Byzantine]], [[History of Bulgaria|Bulgarian]] and [[Medieval Serbia|Serbian]] rulers. According to some authors during the Ottoman rule, the majority of native Torlakian Slavic population did not have distinct national consciousness in ethnic sense.Roudometof, Victor; Robertson, Roland (2001). Nationalism, globalization, and orthodoxy: the social origins of ethnic conflict in the Balkans. Greenwood Publishing Group. pp. 68-71. {{ISBN|0313319499}}. The first known literary monument, influenced by Torlakian dialects is the Manuscript from [[Temštica#Temska|Temska]] Monastery from 1762, in which its author, the Monk [[Kiril Zhivkovich]] from [[Pirot]], considered his language as: "''simple Bulgarian''".Василев, В.П. Темският ръкопис – български езиков паметник от 1764 г, Paleobulgarica, IX (1986), кн. 1, с. 49-72 A [[Silesia]]n traveler stated in 1596 that the road of his trip from Sofia to Niš was filled with corpses and described the gates of Niš as standing in front of freshly beheaded heads of poor Bulgarian peasants by the Ottoman army.{{cite book|title=Kultur der Nationen|page=110|url=https://books.google.bg/books?id=WDAPAQAAIAAJ&q=friedrich+seidel+nis&dq=friedrich+seidel+nis&hl=bg&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwi4lZn4ucLQAhVHB8AKHbgfAwQQ6AEISTAF|language=de}} The [[Pirot Rebellion]] broke out in 1836, followed by the [[Niš rebellion (1841)|Niš rebellion]] in 1836, which also included Pirot. According to Ottoman statistics during the [[Tanzimat]] the greater part of the population up to the [[Sanjak of Niš]] was treated as Bulgarian.[http://www.promacedonia.org/en/mp/index.htm Ottoman Bulgaria in the First Tanzimat Period — The Revolts in Nish (1841) and Vidin (1850) Mark Pinson, Middle Eastern Studies, Vol. 11, No 2 (May, 1975), pp. 103-146.] According to all authors between 1840-72 the delineation between Bulgarians and Serbs is undisputed and ran north of Nis.{{cite book|last1=Light|first1=Andrew|last2=Smith|first2=Jonathan M.|title=Philosophy and Geography II: The Production of Public Space|publisher=Rowman & Littlefield|isbn=9780847688104|url=https://books.google.bg/books?id=s2_Do4Hd8skC&pg=PA240&lpg=PA240&dq=Davidovic+map+1848&source=bl&ots=GNSaAkU3kF&sig=UP5pkrWMTggdOwFuTUXctUSwk9w&hl=en&sa=X&ved=0ahUKEwjHx5eYkOXTAhVELZoKHYqNB24Q6AEILzAF#v=onepage&q&f=false|pages=240, 241|quote=}} The Serbian researchers (such as [[Dimitrije Davidovic]] in 1828 and [[Milan Savić (author)|Milan Savić]] in 1878) also accepted [[South Morava|Bulgarian Morava]] river as such delineation and added Niš outside the borders of the Serbian people.{{cite web|url=https://books.google.bg/books?hl=bg&id=IeNBAAAAYAAJ&dq=%D0%98%D1%81%D1%82%D0%BE%D1%80%D0%B8%D1%98%D0%B0+%D0%91%D1%83%D0%B3%D0%B0%D1%80%D1%81%D0%BA%D0%BE%D0%B3%D0%B0+%D0%BD%D0%B0%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%B4%D0%B0+%D0%B4%D0%BE+%D0%BF%D1%80%D0%BE%D0%BF%D0%B0%D1%81%D1%82%D0%B8+%D0%B4%D1%80%D0%B6%D0%B0%D0%B2%D0%B5&q=%22%D0%B0+%D1%83%D0%BD%D1%83%D1%82%D1%80%D0%B0%22+%22%D0%BD%D0%B8%D1%88%22#search_anchor|title=Istorii︠a︡ na bŭlgarskii︠a︡ narod|work=google.bg}} It was also stipulated the area to be ceded to Bulgaria according to the [[Constantinople Conference]] in 1876 and most of it according to the [[Treaty of San Stefano]] in 1878. From 1870 until then the area was part of the [[Bulgarian Orthodox Church]], before that the area had been under the [[Ecumenical Patriarchate of Constantinople]] and the [[Serbian Patriarchate of Peć]]. Following [[World War I]], four territories, now known to the Bulgarian community as the [[Western Outlands]], passed to the [[Kingdom of Serbs, Croats and Slovenes]] from [[Bulgaria]] as a war indemnity, and the remains of the old border can be seen at [[Vlasina|Vlasina lake]]. In the Interwar Period, the [[Internal Western Outland Revolutionary Organisation]], countering Yugoslav rule in the region, was engaged in repeated attacks against the Yugoslav police and army. During [[World War II]] Bulgaria retook the Western Outlands, as well as [[Pirot]] and [[Vranje]]. After the [[World War II|Second World War]], these regions were returned to Yugoslavia. After [[Serbia]]'s independence, these areas remained within Serbia. ==Notable people== * [[Helena of Bulgaria]], regent of Serbia 1355–1356 * [[Gregory Tsamblak]] (c.1365–1420), medieval writer and cleric == References == {{reflist}} == See also == * [[Western Outlands]] * [[Bulgarians in the Republic of Macedonia]] * [[Bulgarians]] * [[Macedonians (Bulgarians)]] * [[Shopi]] {{Ethnic groups in Serbia}} {{Bulgarian diaspora}} [[Category:Serbian people of Bulgarian descent| ]] [[Category:Bulgarian minorities|Serbia]] [[Category:Ethnic groups in Serbia]] [[Category:Bulgarian diaspora by country|Serbia]]

The '''Canadian Bridge Federation''' (CBF), '''La Fédération Canadienne de Bridge''', is the primary organizational body for [[contract bridge]] in Canada. Like its American counterpart, the [[United States Bridge Federation]], the CBF promotes bridge by running tournaments for youths and adults and provides financial support for teams that represent Canada in international competition. It publishes a magazine, ''Bridge Canada''.
The federation runs a number of community outreach programs which have raised money for Canadian charities, and acts as a liaison with the [[American Contract Bridge League]] (ACBL) and [[World Bridge Federation]] (WBF), ensuring that Canadian concerns are raised with those organizations.<ref>[http://www.cbf.ca/CBFOffice/Membership.html "Support Your National Bridge Federation!"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090125122235/http://cbf.ca/CBFOffice/Membership.html# |date=2009-01-25 }} (membership information). CBF.</ref> The CBF also conducts the annual Canadian Bridge Championships, a multi-tournament event which includes the Canadian National Team Championships, the Canadian Women's Team Championships, the Canadian Open Pair Championships, the Canadian Senior Team Championships, and the Canadian International Master Point (IMP) Championships.<ref name=chips/>
The CBF was created by several prominent Canadian bridge players, including [[Eric Murray (bridge player)|Eric Murray]], during the 1965 Nationals (now called the North American Bridge Championships) in Chicago. At the time, there were more than 10,000 Canadian members of the ACBL. The federation was also a response to the 1960 World Bridge Olympiad created by the WBF - a chance for Canada to compete on an international level.<ref name=history/>
The CBF's current constitution provides for six zones, each represented by a zone director. These zones are grouped more or less according to geography, with directors in Halifax, Ville de Léry (Quebec), Toronto, Winnipeg, Edmonton and Vancouver. The federation's head office is in Saskatoon.<ref>[http://www.cbf.ca/CBFOffice/CBFcontacts.html "CBF Contacts"] {{Webarchive|url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100213232202/http://www.cbf.ca/CBFOffice/CBFcontacts.html# |date=2010-02-13 }}. CBF.</ref>

CEFORA (Argentinean Republic Committee for UFO Phenomena Studies) is an organization formed by various ufology groups in [[Argentina]]. The main purpose is the declassification of all related UFO phenomena in Argentina. It was formed by serious Argentinean ufologists in [[Victoria, Entre Rios]] during a conference. ==Background== CEFORA is the umbrella org for UFO groups and researchers in Argentina.<ref>Open Minds, July 6, 2010 - [http://www.openminds.tv/argentinas-x-files-pt-1/4164 Argentina’s X-Files – Pt 1 Posted by: Antonio Huneeus]</ref><ref>''Info 7'' - [http://www.info7.com.mx/noticia.php?id=93930&secc=19&subsecc=0 Buscan la desclasificación de archivos ovni en Argentina]</ref> The organization has requested heads of the National Ministry of Defense, the National Presidency and the Chamber of Deputies that they declassify all info in relation to UFO activity in Argentina.<ref>''UFO Digest'', May 5, 2009 - [http://www.ufodigest.com/news/0509/signature.php Argentina: A One Million-Signature Goal by Scott Corrales]</ref> The director of the organization is Silvia Pérez Simondini. Simondini also runs the Visión OVNI UFO Museum which is in the [[Entre Ríos Province|Entre Ríos]] city of Victoria.<ref>''AIM Digital'', 18 Aug. 2016 - [http://www.aimdigital.com.ar/2016/08/19/el-ojo-un-misterio-a-develar/ El ojo, un misterio a develar]</ref><ref>Open Minds, June 10, 2011 - [http://www.openminds.tv/argentinean-air-force-ufo-commission-709/10166 Argentinean Air Force launches new UFO commission Posted by: Antonio Huneeus]</ref>

{{Atheism sidebar|types}} '''Christian atheism''' is a form of [[cultural Christian]]ity and ethics system drawing its beliefs and practices from [[Jesus]]' life and teachings as recorded in the [[New Testament]] [[Gospels]] and other sources, whilst rejecting [[supernatural]] claims of [[Christianity]]. Christian atheism takes many forms: some Christian atheists take a [[Theology|theological]] position in which the belief in the transcendent or interventionist [[God in Christianity|God]] is rejected or absent in favor of finding God totally in the world ([[Thomas J. J. Altizer]]) while others follow [[Jesus in Christianity|Jesus]] in a godless world ([[William Hamilton (theologian)|William Hamilton]]). Hamilton's Christian atheism is similar to [[Jesuism]]. == Beliefs == [[File:2005-11-20 - United Kingdom - England - London - Hyde Park - Speakers' Corner 4887898959.jpg|thumb|A man promoting Christian atheism at [[Speakers' Corner]], London, in 2005. One of his placards reads: "To follow Jesus, reject God".]] Thomas Ogletree, Frederick Marquand Professor of Ethics and Religious Studies at [[Yale Divinity School]], lists these four common beliefs:{{cite web|last=Ogletree|first=Thomas|title=professor at Yale University|url=http://religiousstudies.yale.edu/people/thomas-ogletree|accessdate=6 April 2017}}Ogletree, Thomas W. The Death of God Controversy. New York: Abingdon Press, 1966. # The assertion of the unreality of God for our age, including the understandings of God which have been a part of traditional Christian [[theology]]. # The insistence upon coming to grips with contemporary [[culture]] as a necessary feature of responsible theological work. # Varying degrees and forms of alienation from the church as it is now constituted. # Recognition of the centrality of the person of [[Jesus]] in theological reflection. == God's existence == According to [[Paul van Buren]], a [[Death of God theology|Death of God theologian]], the word God itself is "either meaningless or misleading". Van Buren contends that it is impossible to think about God and says:
We cannot identify anything which will count for or against the truth of our statements concerning 'God'.
The inference from these claims to the "either meaningless or misleading" conclusion is implicitly premised on the [[Verificationism|verificationist theory of meaning]]. Most Christian atheists believe that God never existed, but there are a few who believe in the death of God literally.Lyas, Colin. "On the Coherence of Christian Atheism." ''The Journal of the Royal Institute of Philosophy'' 45(171): 1970. [[Thomas J. J. Altizer]] is a well-known Christian atheist who is known for his literal approach to the death of God. He often speaks of God's death as a redemptive event. In his book ''The Gospel of Christian Atheism'', he says:
Every man today who is open to experience knows that God is absent, but only the Christian knows that God is dead, that the death of God is a final and irrevocable event and that God's death has actualized in our history a new and liberated humanity.Altizer, Thomas J. J. ''The Gospel of Christian Atheism''. Philadelphia: The Westminster Press, 1966.
== Dealing with culture == Theologians including Altizer and Lyas looked at the scientific, empirical culture of today and tried to find religion's place in it. In Altizer's words:
No longer can faith and the world exist in mutual isolation…the radical Christian condemns all forms of faith that are disengaged with the world.
He goes on to say that our response to atheism should be one of "acceptance and affirmation". Colin Lyas, a Philosophy lecturer at [[Lancaster University]], stated:
Christian atheists are united also in the belief that any satisfactory answer to these problems must be an answer that will make life tolerable in this world, here and now and which will direct attention to the social and other problems of this life.
== Separation from the church == Thomas Altizer has said:
[T]he radical Christian believes that the [[Ecclesiology|ecclesiastical]] tradition has ceased to be Christian.
Altizer believed that orthodox Christianity no longer had any meaning to people because it did not discuss Christianity within the context of contemporary theology. Christian atheists want to be completely separated from most orthodox Christian beliefs and biblical traditions.Altizer, Thomas J. J. and William Hamilton. ''Radical Theology and The Death of God''. New York: The Bobbs-Merrill Company, Inc.,1966. Altizer states that a faith will not be completely pure if it is open to modern culture. This faith "can never identify itself with an ecclesiastical tradition or with a given doctrinal or ritual form". He goes on to say that faith cannot "have any final assurance as to what it means to be a Christian". Altizer said: "We must not, he says, seek for the sacred by saying 'no' to the radical profanity of our age, but by saying 'yes' to it". They see religions which withdraw from the world as moving away from truth. This is part of the reason why they see the existence of God as counter-progressive. Altizer wrote of God as the enemy to man because mankind could never reach its fullest potential while God existed. He went on to state that "to cling to the Christian God in our time is to evade the human situation of our century and to renounce the inevitable suffering which is its lot". == Centrality of Jesus == {{See also|Jesuism}} [[File:Christus Ravenna Mosaic.jpg|thumb|left|6th-century [[mosaic]] of Jesus at [[Basilica of Sant'Apollinare Nuovo]] in [[Ravenna]]]] Although Jesus is still a central feature of Christian atheism, Hamilton said that to the Christian atheist, Jesus as an historical or supernatural figure is not the foundation of faith; instead, Jesus is a "place to be, a standpoint". Christian atheists look to Jesus as an example of what a Christian should be, but they do not see him as God, nor as the [[Son of God]]; merely as an influential [[rabbi]]. Hamilton wrote that following Jesus means being "alongside the neighbor, being for him" and that to follow Jesus means to be human, to help other humans, and to further humankind. Other Christian atheists such as [[Thomas Altizer]] preserve the divinity of Jesus, arguing that through him God negates God's transcendence of being. ==By denomination== ===Protestantism=== In the Netherlands, 42% of the members of the [[Protestant Church in the Netherlands]] (PKN) are [[Nontheism|nontheists]].God in Nederland' (1996–2006), by Ronald Meester, G. Dekker, {{ISBN|9789025957407}} Non-belief among clergymen is not always perceived as a problem. Some follow the tradition of "Christian non-realism", most famously expounded in the United Kingdom by [[Don Cupitt]] in the 1980s, which holds that God is a symbol or metaphor and that religious language is not matched by a transcendent reality. According to an investigation of 860 pastors in seven Dutch Protestant denominations, 1 in 6 clergy are either agnostic or atheist. In one of those denominations, the Remonstrant Brotherhood, the number of doubters was 42 percent.{{cite news|last=Pigott|first=Robert|title=Dutch rethink Christianity for a doubtful world|url=https://www.bbc.co.uk/news/world-europe-14417362|accessdate=2 October 2011|newspaper=BBC News|date=5 August 2011}}{{cite web|url=http://www.albertmohler.com/2009/03/31/does-your-pastor-believe-in-god-2/|title=Does Your Pastor Believe in God?|work=albertmohler.com}} A minister of the PKN, [[Klaas Hendrikse]] has described God as "a word for experience, or human experience" and said that Jesus may have [[Christ myth theory|never existed]]. Hendrikse gained attention with his book published in November 2007 in which he said that it was not necessary to believe in God's existence in order to believe in God. The Dutch title of the book translates as ''Believing in a God Who Does Not Exist: Manifesto of An Atheist Pastor''. Hendrikse writes in the book that "God is for me not a being but a word for what can happen between people. Someone says to you, for example, 'I will not abandon you', and then makes those words come true. It would be perfectly alright to call that [relationship] God". A General Synod found Hendrikse's views were widely shared among both clergy and church members. The February 3, 2010 decision to allow Hendrikse to continue working as a pastor followed the advice of a regional supervisory panel that the statements by Hendrikse "are not of sufficient weight to damage the foundations of the Church. The ideas of Hendrikse are theologically not new, and are in keeping with the liberal tradition that is an integral part of our church", the special panel concluded. A [[Harris Insights & Analytics|Harris Interactive]] survey from 2003 found that 90% of self-identified [[Protestantism|Protestants]] in the [[United States]] believe in God and about 4% of American Protestants believe there is no God.{{cite web|format=PDF|author=Humphrey Taylor|url=http://www.harrisinteractive.com/vault/Harris-Interactive-Poll-Research-While-Most-Americans-Believe-in-God-Only-36-pct-A-2003-10.pdf|title=While Most Americans Believe in God, Only 36% Attend a Religious Service Once a Month or More Often|work=The Harris Poll #59|date=October 15, 2003|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20101206042041/http://www.harrisinteractive.com/vault/Harris-Interactive-Poll-Research-While-Most-Americans-Believe-in-God-Only-36-pct-A-2003-10.pdf|archivedate=December 6, 2010}} ===Catholicism=== Catholic atheism is a [[belief]] in which the culture, traditions, rituals and norms of [[Catholicism]] are accepted, but the existence of God is rejected. It is illustrated in [[Miguel de Unamuno]]'s novel ''[[San Manuel Bueno, Mártir]]'' (1930). According to research in 2007, only 27% of Catholics in the Netherlands considered themselves [[theist]] while 55% were [[ietsism|ietsist]] or [[deism|agnostic deist]] and 17% were [[agnostic]] or [[atheist]]. Many Dutch people still affiliate with the term "Catholic" and use it within certain traditions as a basis of their cultural identity, rather than as a religious identity. The vast majority of the Catholic population in the Netherlands is now largely irreligious in practice. == Criticisms == In his book ''[[Mere Christianity]]'', the [[apologist]] [[C. S. Lewis]] objected to Hamilton's version of Christian atheism and the claim that Jesus was merely a moral guide:
I am trying here to prevent anyone saying the really foolish thing that people often say about Him: 'I'm ready to accept Jesus as a great moral teacher, but I don't accept his claim to be God.' That is the one thing we must not say. A man who was merely a man and said the sort of things Jesus said would not be a great moral teacher. He would either be a lunatic—on the level with the man who says he is a poached egg—or else he would be the Devil of Hell. You must make your choice. Either this man was, and is, the Son of God, or else a madman or something worse. You can shut him up for a fool, you can spit at him and kill him as a demon or you can fall at his feet and call him Lord and God, but let us not come with any patronising nonsense about his being a great human teacher. He has not left that open to us. He did not intend to. [...] Now it seems to me obvious that He was neither a lunatic nor a fiend: and consequently, however strange or terrifying or unlikely it may seem, I have to accept the view that He was and is God.
Lewis's argument, now known as [[Lewis's trilemma]], has been criticized for, among other things, constituting a [[false trilemma]]{{How?|date=October 2018}}. Philosopher John Beversluis argues that Lewis "deprives his readers of numerous alternate interpretations of Jesus that carry with them no such odious implications".John Beversluis, ''C.S. Lewis and the Search for Rational Religion'' (Grand Rapids: Eerdmans, 1985), p 56. == Notable people == * [[William Montgomery Brown]] (1855–1937): American Episcopal bishop, communist author and atheist activist. He described himself as "Christian Atheist".{{cite news | title=U.S. Heresy Trial. A "Christian Atheist." | newspaper=The Times | date=2 June 1924 | page=13 | issue=43667}} col C. * [[Douglas Murray (author)|Douglas Murray]] (1979): British author, journalist and political commentator. He is a former [[Anglican]] who believes Christianity to be an important influence on British and European culture.{{cite news| url=http://www.spectator.co.uk/features/3194231/studying-islam-has-made-me-an-atheist/ | title=Studying Islam has made me an atheist | date=December 29, 2008}}{{cite news|title=This House Believes Religion Has No Place In The 21st Century|url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=-XpEjVlPFrs|publisher=The Cambridge Union Society|date=31 January 2013}}{{cite news| url=http://www.samharris.org/podcast/item/on-the-maintenance-of-civilization/ | title=On the Maintenance of Civilization | date=November 22, 2015}}{{cite news|last1=Holloway|first1=Richard|title=Sunday Morning With...|url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/programmes/b08pgz87|publisher=BBC Radio Scotland|date=7 May 2017|archiveurl=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=PXcN3IBMyYk|archivedate=7 May 2017}} * [[Anton Rubinstein]] (1829–1894): [[Russian Empire|Russian]] [[pianist]], [[composer]] and [[Conducting|conductor]]. Although he was raised as a Christian, Rubinstein later became a Christian atheist.[[#Taylor|Taylor]], 280. * [[Dan Savage]] (1964): American author, media [[Pundit (expert)|pundit]], journalist and activist for the [[LGBT community]]. While he has stated that he is now an atheist,"If Osama bin Laden were in charge, he would slit my throat; my God, I'm an atheist, a hedonist, and a faggot." ''Skipping Towards Gomorrah: The Seven Deadly Sins and the Pursuit of Happiness in America'' Dan Savage, Plume, 2002, p. 258. he has said that he still identifies as "culturally Catholic".{{cite web|author=Anderson-Minshall, Diane|url=http://www.afterelton.com/archive/elton/print/2005/9/dansavage.html|title=Interview with Dan Savage|date=September 13, 2005|publisher=AfterElton.com}} * [[Gretta Vosper]] (1958): [[United Church of Canada]] minister who is an atheist.{{cite news |title=Atheist minister praises the glory of good at Scarborough church |first=Eric |last=Andrew-Gee |journal=[[Toronto Star]] |date=16 March 2015 |url=https://www.thestar.com/news/gta/2015/03/16/atheist-minister-praises-the-glory-of-good-at-scarborough-church.html |quote=Vosper herself is a bit heterodox on the question of Christ. Asked if she believes that Jesus was the son of God, she said, ‘I don’t think Jesus ''was.''’ That is, she doesn’t think He existed at all.}} == See also == {{portal|Christianity|Atheism}} {{Div col|colwidth=20em}} * ''[[Asimov's Guide to the Bible]]'' * [[Christian agnosticism]] * [[Christian communism]] * [[Christ myth theory]] * [[Demythologization]] * ''[[Jefferson Bible]]'' * [[Jewish atheism]] * [[Lloyd Geering]] * [[Luboš Motl]] * [[Nontheist Friends]] * [[Nontheistic religion]] * [[Postchristianity]] * [[Robert Jensen]] * [[Robert M. Price]] * [[Sea of Faith]] * [[Thorkild Grosbøll]] {{div col end}} == References == {{Reflist}} == Further reading == * {{cite book | first=M. Joles | last=Soury | title=Un athée catholique | year=1910 | publisher=E. Vitte | asin=B001BQPY7G }} * {{cite book | first=Thomas J. J. | last=Altizer | title=The New Gospel of Christian Atheism | year=2002 | publisher=The Davies Group | ISBN=1-888570-65-2 }} * Hamilton, William, ''A Quest for the Post-Historical Jesus'', (London, New York: Continuum International Publishing Group, 1994). {{ISBN|978-0-8264-0641-5}}. == External links == {{Wikiquote}} * [http://www.atheists-for-jesus.com/ Atheists for Jesus] [[Category:Atheism]] [[Category:Christian secularism]] [[Category:Christian theological movements|Atheism]] [[Category:Christianity and other religions]] [[Category:Christianity and society|Atheism]] [[Category:Death of God theology]] [[Category:Radical theology]]
