{{Use dmy dates|date=April 2013}} {{Infobox person | name = Ernst Jansen Steur | image = | nationality = Netherlands | birth_place = [[Kamperland]] | birth_date = 24 October 1945 | birth_name = Ernst Nicolaas Herman Jansen | alma mater = [[Maastricht University]] (dr.) | module = {{Infobox medical details | profession = Physician | field = [[Neurologist]] | work_institutions = [[Medisch Spectrum Twente]], the Schlossberg Klinik in Bad Laasphe and the Klinik am Gesundbrunnen hospital in Heilbronn | research_field = [[Alzheimer's disease]], [[Parkinson's disease]] and [[multiple sclerosis]]}} }}
'''Ernst Nicolaas Herman Jansen''', (born 24 October 1945 in [[Kamperland]], [[Netherlands]]),<ref name="Geboorteaankondiging">{{cite web|url=http://zoeken.krantenbankzeeland.nl/index.php?datering=29-10-1945&krant=vst&q=ernst|title=Profile: geboorteaankondiging|language=Dutch|trans-title=Announcement of birth|date=29 October 1945|work=Vrije stemmen. Dagblad voor Zeeland|accessdate=12 January 2013|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20131206231840/http://zoeken.krantenbankzeeland.nl/index.php?datering=29-10-1945&krant=vst&q=ernst|archivedate=6 December 2013}}</ref> later known as '''Ernst Jansen Steur''', is a former Dutch [[neurologist]], who garnered notoriety for misconduct and lost his license to practice medicine.
==Career== Ernst Nicolaas Herman Jansen, later known as Ernst Jansen Steur<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.nu.nl/binnenland/3613309/chronologie-zaak-ernst-jansen-steur.html|title=Chronologie zaak Ernst Jansen Steur - NU - Het laatste nieuws het eerst op NU.nl|website=Nu.nl|accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref> is a Dutch former [[neurologist]] who worked in several positions, including the [[Medisch Spectrum Twente]] (MST). During his career he was noted within his profession for his research into [[Alzheimer's disease]], [[Parkinson's disease]] and [[multiple sclerosis]].<ref name="DokterBibber">{{cite news|title='Dokter Bibber', waarom?|author=Jan Colijn|author2=Charles Sanders|url=http://www.telegraaf.nl/binnenland/20502749/___Dokter_Bibber___waarom___.html|newspaper=De Telegraaf|date=20 September 2009|accessdate=13 January 2013|language=Dutch|trans-title='Dr. Shaky, why?' (note: 'Dr. Bibber' is also the Dutch name of the Hasbro game "Operation")}}</ref>
He completed his [[doctorate|doctoral research]] in 1994 at the [[Maastricht University]], researching Parkinson's disease.<ref name="promotieRUL">{{cite web|url=http://arno.unimaas.nl/show.cgi?fid=6813|title=Parkinson's Disease – some pharmacotherapeutic aspects|last1=Jansen|first1=Ernst N.H.|date=2 June 1994|work=doctoral thesis|accessdate=12 January 2013}}</ref>
Jansen Steur was interviewed as an expert on the disease by the Dutch television program ''[[EénVandaag]]'' on 24 July 2002 regarding the condition of [[Prince Claus of the Netherlands]] (Jansen Steur indicated on the show that he found the prince's condition "worrisome").<ref name="BeeldenGeluidEenVandaag">{{cite web|url=http://zoeken.beeldengeluid.nl/internet/index.aspx?chapterid=1164&filterid=974&contentid=7&verityID=/14140/17349/17290/53797/78444@selectiesl#anchor_item_1 |title=De gezondheidstoestand van Prins Claus|date=24 July 2002|work=EenVandaag, item 1|language=Dutch|trans-title=The state of the health of Prince Claus|accessdate=12 January 2013}}</ref>
Jansen Steur sufferent a serious car accident in Germany<ref name=":0">{{Cite news|url=http://www.nrc.nl/handelsblad/van/2015/mei/02/het-brein-van-neuroloog-jansen-was-een-gatenkaas-1494015|title=The brain had holes like Swiss cheese|last=Toonen|first=Anette|date=2 May 2015|language=Dutch}}</ref> in 1990, resulting in a complex [[hip fracture]]. In 2000 he became addicted to [[Midazolam]], a sedative. In order to obtain this drug he started forging [[Medical prescription|prescription]]s using his colleagues' names as prescribing physicians.<ref name="DokterBibber"/>
As it turned out later, in the four years following his becoming addicted, he regularly misdiagnosed patients. In order to support his misdiagnoses, he forged diagnostic [[questionnaire]]s from patients, swapped patient [[Medical radiography|x-rays]] and forged laboratory results. He prescribed strong medications unnecessarily for a number of his patients and in a number of cases had patients undergo [[Neurosurgery|brain surgery]] without necessity.<ref name="VKomsterdenNeuroloogWerktWeer">{{cite news|title=Omstreden neuroloog werkt weer in Duits ziekenhuis|url=http://www.volkskrant.nl/vk/nl/5270/Zorg/article/detail/3372278/2013/01/04/Omstreden-neuroloog-werkt-weer-in-Duits-ziekenhuis.dhtml|newspaper=De Volkskrant|date=4 January 2012|language=Dutch|trans-title=Controversial neurologist back at work in German hospital}}</ref>
Jansen Steur was forced to resign from the MST by the board in 2004. He received a €250.000 severance package and was forced to sign a non-disclosure agreement (together with his former colleagues).<ref name="DokterBibber"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skipr.nl/actueel/id247-medisch-spectrum-twente-zwijgplicht-over-neuroloog.html|title=Medisch Spectrum Twente: zwijgplicht over neuroloog|date=19 January 2009|language=Dutch|trans-title=Medisch Spectrum Twente:oath of secrecy regarding neurlogist}}</ref> As part of this deal, he agreed to strike himself from the Dutch [[Licensure|registry]] of medical professionals, thereby giving up the right to practice in the Netherlands. Patients received financial compensation, but were sworn to secrecy.<ref>{{cite news|title=Neuroloog deed zonder toestemming bloedonderzoek|url=http://www.tubantia.nl/regio/neuroloog-deed-zonder-toestemming-bloedonderzoek-1.2617020|newspaper=TC Tubantia|language=Dutch|trans-title=Neurologist performed blood tests without permission|accessdate=8 October 2017}}</ref>
==Investigation and prosecution== Despite the deal with Jansen Steur (resulting in his resignation from MST and voluntary removal from the registry), the board of MST decided to begin an investigation in 2009 due to a turnover of board members which included the installation of {{ill|Herre Kingma|nl}} as the new chairman.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.neurologie.nl/uploads/89/1946/Lemstra_II.pdf|title=Heel de patiënt – Het handelen van de beroepsmatig betrokkenen na het vertrek van een disfunctionerende medisch specialist|date=2 September 2010|work=report of the Tweede externe onderzoekscommissie MST|language=Dutch|format=PDF}}</ref> The investigation was headed by {{Interlanguage link multi|Wolter Lemstra|nl}}, the former mayor of [[Hengelo]]. The Lemstra committee reported on 1 September 2009, concluding failures on the part of the MST but also of the Dutch Health Care Inspectorate ({{nl}}: ''Inspectie voor de Gezondheidszorg'' or ''IGZ''), which was headed by Kingma at the time that Jansen was being sent away from the MST.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://zoek.officielebekendmakingen.nl/kst-31700-XVI-176.html?zoekcriteria=%3fzkt%3dUitgebreid%26pst%3dTractatenblad%257CStaatsblad%257CStaatscourant%257CGemeenteblad%257CProvincieblad%257CWaterschapsblad%257CParlementaireDocumenten%26vrt%3dcommissie%2blemstra%26zkd%3dInDeGeheleText%26dpr%3dAnderePeriode%26spd%3d20090106%26epd%3d20100106%26sdt%3dDatumPublicatie%26ap%3d%26pnr%3d1%26rpp%3d10&resultIndex=9&sorttype=1&sortorder=4|title=31 700 XVI Vaststelling van de begrotingsstaten van het Ministerie van Volksgezondheid, Welzijn en Sport (XVI) voor het jaar 2009|last=Klink|first=Ab|date=9 September 2009|work=Aanbiedingsbrief rapport aan Tweede Kamer|publisher=Ministry of Health|language=Dutch}}</ref><ref>{{cite news|title=Kritiek op rapport omstreden neuroloog|url=http://www.parool.nl/parool/nl/224/BINNENLAND/article/detail/260592/2009/09/01/Kritiek-op-rapport-omstreden-neuroloog.dhtml|newspaper=Het Parool|date=1 September 2009|language=Dutch|trans-title=Criticism of report controversial neurologist}}</ref> The committee also concluded Jansen had been failing as a doctor since 1992 and that the MST had failed to address the situation for years.<ref name="NOSinspectieFaalde"/>
Upon the release of this report, the [[Ministry of Health, Welfare and Sport (Netherlands)|Dutch minister of Health]] [[Ab Klink]] instituted another investigative committee headed by [[Rein Jan Hoekstra]], to investigate the functioning of the Health Care Inspectorate.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://zoek.officielebekendmakingen.nl/blg-67447.html?zoekcriteria=%3fzkt%3dUitgebreid%26pst%3dTractatenblad%257CStaatsblad%257CStaatscourant%257CGemeenteblad%257CProvincieblad%257CWaterschapsblad%257CParlementaireDocumenten%26vrt%3dcommissie%2bhoekstra%26zkd%3dInDeGeheleText%26dpr%3dAnderePeriode%26spd%3d20100505%26epd%3d20100606%26sdt%3dDatumPublicatie%26ap%3d%26pnr%3d1%26rpp%3d10&resultIndex=2&sorttype=1&sortorder=4|title=Angel en Antenne, Het functioneren van de Inspectie voor de Gezondheidszorg in de casus van de neuroloog van het Medisch Spectrum Twente|author=R. J. Hoekstra|authorlink=Rein Jan Hoekstra|date=May 2012|work=Bijlage bij Kamerstuk 32123-XVI nr. 139|accessdate=13 January 2013}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.skipr.nl/actueel/id4420-commissie-hoekstra-igz-moet-werkwijze-verbeteren.html|title=Commissie Hoekstra: 'IGZ moet werkwijze verbeteren'|date=27 May 2010|work=Skipr.nl|accessdate=13 January 2013}}</ref>
This committee supported the conclusions of the Lemstra committee regarding the failing of the Inspectorate, concluding that the Inspectorate waited far too long to take measures against Jansen and should have filed criminal charges against him rather than settling for a voluntary relinquishing of his status as a physician. They also criticized the MST and the doctors treating Jansen Steur for his injuries in that they did not cooperate fully with the investigation by the Inspectorate. Both of Jansen's doctors invoked [[physician–patient privilege]].<ref name="NOSinspectieFaalde">{{cite web|url=http://nos.nl/artikel/160112-inspectie-faalde-in-zaak-verslaafde-neuroloog.html|title=Inspectie faalde in zaak verslaafde neuroloog|last=Van den Brink|first=Rinke|date=27 May 2010|work=nos.nl|publisher=NOS|language=Dutch|trans-title=Inspectorate failed in case of addicted neurologist|accessdate=13 January 2013}}</ref> However, the Inspectorate concluded in an internal investigation concluded on 17 February 2009 that they had functioned correctly in the matter of Jansen Steur.<ref name="NOSinspectieFaalde"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.rijksoverheid.nl/documenten-en-publicaties/kamerstukken/2009/02/20/igz-rapportage-neuroloog-mst.html|title=IGZ rapportage neuroloog MST|work=Records of the Dutch Parliament|publisher=Dutch government|language=Dutch|trans-title=IGZ report neurologist MST|accessdate=13 January 2013}}</ref>
It was announced in October 2009 that Jansen Steur would have to face charges in court after all, charges having been leveled by a special investigative team of the police for this case (the Lippstadt-team). The team had, by that point, gathered 135 different complaints from patients regarding Jansen Steur.<ref name="DokterBibber"/><ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraaf.nl/binnenland/20401004/__Omstreden_neuroloog_voor_de_rechter__.html|title=Omstreden neuroloog voor de rechter|date=7 October 2009|work=Telegraaf.nl|publisher=Telegraaf Media Groep|language=Dutch|trans-title=Controversial neurologist to appear in court|accessdate=13 January 2013}}</ref> The justice department called the case "the biggest medical trial in the Netherlands ever".<ref name="VKomsterdenNeuroloogWerktWeer"/>
The trial was started on 28 November 2012; it was announced on this first trial day that Jansen Steur was facing 21 criminal charges, including causing grievous bodily and mental harm through misdiagnoses of eight patients, causing one patient to commit suicide, theft, embezzlement and fraud. A total of 40 people filed charges against the doctor.<ref name="NOSneuroloogWeigertOnderzoek">{{cite web|url=http://nos.nl/artikel/445504-neuroloog-weigert-onderzoek.html|title=Neuroloog weigert onderzoek|date=28 November 2012|language=Dutch|trans-title=Neurologist refuses investigation|work=NOS.nl|publisher=NOS|accessdate=13 January 2013}}</ref>
There were charges filed by [[personal injury]] expert {{Interlanguage link multi|Yme Drost|nl}}, who filed charges in name of a few dozen injured patients and in name of the families of three patients who died after having been treated by Jansen Steur.<ref name="TelegraafDerdeDode">{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraaf.nl/binnenland/20502544/__Aangifte_dode_in_affaire_neuroloog__.html|title=Aangifte derde dode in affaire neuroloog|last=Colijn|first=Jan|last2=Sanders|first2=Charles|date=19 September 2009|work=Telegraaf.nl|publisher=Telegraaf Media Groep|language=Dutch|trans-title=Charges regarding third death filed in case of controversial neurologist|accessdate=13 January 2013}}</ref> In addition to these charges, charges were filed of scientific fraud, after investigation by the Lemstra committee showed that Jansen Steur had falsified results in order to publish an article in ''[[The Lancet]]''.<ref name="TelegraafDerdeDode"/> The court in [[Arnhem]] sentenced him for deliberately setting misdiagnosis, wrongly prescribing strong medicines and the denial of care. In addition he was considered responsible for a suicide of a female patient due to his diagnosis. The court sentenced in February 2014 3 years of prison.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nu.nl/binnenland/3698771/oud-neuroloog-ernst-jansen-steur-krijgt-drie-jaar-cel.html|title=Three years cell|date=11 February 2014|access-date=5 May 2015|language=Dutch}}</ref> Jansen Steur appealed.
[[Metta de Noo]], a physician and acquaintance of Jansen Steur claimed in her book of 2015 that he suffered a [[frontal lobe disorder]] due to the 1990 accident and should not be held criminally accountable.<ref>{{Cite news|url=http://www.nu.nl/binnenland/4043571/ex-neuroloog-jansen-steur-mogelijk-zelf-niet-bij-hoger-beroep.html|title=Appeal|website=Nu.nl|date=5 May 2015|access-date=5 May 2015}}</ref><ref name=":0"/>
==Work in Germany after 2004== After being forced out of the MST in 2004, Jansen Steur moved to Germany, where he worked for several [[clinic|private clinics]]. After Dutch correspondent [[Rob Vorkink]] tracked him down to the Schlossberg Klinik in [[Bad Laasphe]] and tried to interview him for [[RTV Oost]], Jansen Steur was immediately fired from that institute.<ref name="DokterBibber"/>
The Netherlands was shocked on 4 January 2013 when the [[Nederlandse Omroep Stichting|NOS evening news]] led with the story that Jansen Steur had found another job as a neurologist in the ''Klinik am Gesundbrunnen'' hospital in [[Heilbronn]]. He was discovered there by the same Rob Vorkink, who recognized Jansen Steur's voice in a phone call (despite his denying that he was the same person). NOS reporter [[Marc Hamer]] verified his identity by passing around photographs among hospital personnel.<ref name="rtvOostExNeuroloogAanHetWerkInDuitsland"/><ref name="NOSGerriEickhofErIsMaarEenNeuroloog"/> He was subsequently fired from the hospital on 5 January 2013.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://nos.nl/artikel/458522-jansen-steur-ontslagen-in-heilbronn.html|title=Ontslag Jansen Steur in Heilbronn|date=5 January 2013|work=NOS.nl|publisher=NOS|language=Dutch|trans-title=Jansen Steur fired from Heilbronn|accessdate=5 January 2013}}</ref>
Although the hospital noted at first that Jansen Steur had been allowed to work at the hospital because he left his profession voluntarily in the Netherlands in 2010 (preventing the hospital from checking his credentials with the Dutch registry) and as there were no criminal convictions against him when he applied to the hospital,<ref name="rtvOostExNeuroloogAanHetWerkInDuitsland">{{cite web|url=http://www.rtvoost.nl/nieuws/default.aspx?cat=1&nid=156156|title=Ex-neuroloog Jansen Steur aan het werk in Duitsland|date=4 January 2013|publisher=RTV Oost|language=Dutch|trans-title=Former neurologist Jansen Steur back at work in Germany}}</ref><ref name="NOSGerriEickhofErIsMaarEenNeuroloog">{{cite web|url=http://nos.nl/video/458320-gerri-eickhof-er-is-maar-een-neuroloog-die-jansen-steur-heet.html|title=Gerri Eickhof: er is maar een neuroloog die Jansen Steur heet|last=Eickhof|first=Gerri|date=4 January 2013|work=NOS.nl|publisher=NOS|language=Dutch|accessdate=13 January 2013}}</ref> it soon transpired that the hospital had in fact been aware of Jansens past.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nu.nl/binnenland/2997699/kliniek-wist-van-verleden-jansen-steur.html|title='Kliniek wist van verleden Jansen Steur'|date=6 January 2013|work=Nu.nl|language=Dutch|trans-title=Clinic was aware of past Jansen Steur}}</ref>
On 6 January 2013, a German patient filed charges over treatment she received from Jansen Steur in [[Heilbronn]], which she claimed left her wheelchair-bound.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.telegraaf.nl/binnenland/21200289/__Wel_ingreep_in_Heilbronn__.html|title='Jansen Steur deed wel ingreep in Heilbronn'|date=6 January 2013|work=Telegraaf.nl|publisher=Telegraaf Media Groep|language=Dutch|trans-title=Jansen Steur did perform procedure in Heilbronn|accessdate=13 January 2013}}</ref>
==Other== Steur is the doctor's mother's maiden name. He added this name to his surname of "Jansen", which is one of the [[List of the most common surnames in Europe#Netherlands|most common surnames in the Netherlands]], and is known to the general public as "Ernst Jansen Steur".<ref name="Geboorteaankondiging"/><ref name="DokterBibber"/>
==References== {{Reflist}}
==External links== *[http://www.aerztezeitung.de/praxis_wirtschaft/klinikmanagement/article/829511/skandalarzt-heilbronn-wieviel-schuld-tragen-klinik-kammern.html German language article treating the question how he was able to work in Germany after getting fired and losing his license as a doctor in the Netherlands], "Wieviel Schuld tragen Klinik und Kammern?", ''Ärzte Zeitung'', 14 January 2013.

{{Romani people}} '''Gurbeti''' is a sub-group of the [[Romani people]] living in former [[Yugoslavia]],<ref>{{cite book |title=Between Past and Future |last=Guy |first=Will |year=2001 |publisher=[[University of Hertfordshire|University of Hertfordshire Press]] |isbn=978-1-902806-07-5 |page=52 }}</ref><ref>{{cite book |title=Serbia Since 1989 |last=Ramet |first=Sabrina P. |author2=Vjeran Pavlaković |year=2005 |publisher=[[University of Washington Press]] |isbn=978-0-295-98538-1 |page=383 }}</ref> which members are predominantly [[Muslim]]s.<ref>{{cite journal |last=Rushton |first=J. Philippe |author2=Jelena Čvorović |author3=Trudy Ann Bons |date=January–February 2007 |title=General mental ability in South Asians: Data from three Roma (Gypsy) communities in Serbia |journal=Intelligence |volume=35 |issue=1 |pages=1–12 |doi=10.1016/j.intell.2006.09.002 }}</ref> In Kosovo, other Romani groups viewed the Gurbeti as being worse and foul.<ref>{{cite book|title=Etnološki pregled: Revue d'etnologie|volume=10-12|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=jrkWAQAAMAAJ|year=1972|page=30}}</ref>
==History== In [[Vuk Stefanović Karadžić]]'s Serbian dictionary, the word ''Gurbet'' means "Gypsy wanderer". The word is derived from Turkish ''gurbet'', meaning "emigrate".<ref>Đura Daničić, Jugoslavenska akademija znanosti i umjetnosti 1891: "U Vukovu rječniku. GUBBET, m. Ciganin skitač, arap. tur. ghurbet, ise\avane. — isporedi gurbetaš, gurbetin."</ref> The first mentions of nomadic Roma attributed as Gurbeti ancestors, mostly Rroma escaping slavery in Wallachia, is from the 17th century.<ref>Helena Kanyar-Becker 2003: "In addition, in the XVIIth century, one begins to find mentions of nomadic Rroma, mostly Rroma who were escaping the slavery in Valachia - the ancestors of the present-day Gurbeti in Yugoslavia."</ref> The Gurbeti Roma's ancestors left Wallachia and Moldavia in the 19th century after abolition of slavery. In 1941, most of the Yugoslav Roma settled permanently, with the exception of the Gurbeti in Montenegro.<ref>{{cite book |title=Serbia Since 1989 |last=Ramet |first=Sabrina P. |author2=Vjeran Pavlaković |year=2005 |publisher=[[University of Washington Press]] |isbn=978-0-295-98538-1 |page=383 }}</ref>
==Culture== They share some cultural features with the [[Kalderaš]], but also with other Roma such as [[Xoraxane]]. Gurbeti are partly assimilated into society and do not fully follow the Romany Law. They speak Gurbeti, a sub-dialect of the [[Vlax Romani language]], or sometimes regarded a separate dialect.
==Diaspora== There is a Gurbeti diaspora, such as in Austria, were recent migrants, mostly unskilled workers, has since integrated into Austrian society.
==Language== Their language ("Gurbeti") is a variety of South [[Vlach Romani language]]s.<ref name="HornbergBrüggemann2013">{{cite book|author1=Sabine Hornberg|author2=Christian Brüggemann|title=Die Bildungssituation von Roma in Europa|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=_bU9AQAAQBAJ&pg=PA58|year=2013|publisher=Waxmann Verlag|isbn=978-3-8309-7841-1|pages=58–}}</ref> In Kosovo, the Gurbeti speech have either a dominant Serbian substratum, or Albanian substratum. The '''Džambazi''' speak a sub-dialect of Gurbeti. The origin of the Romani loan words in Croatian are most likely from Gurbeti, who settled predominantly from Bosnia and Herzegovina.<ref>Schrammel-Ambrosch-Halwachs 2005, p. 85</ref> Rade Uhlik translated the ''[[Gospel of Luke]]'' into Bosnian Gurbeti as ''O keriben pal e Devleskre bičhade''. This was published by the British and Foreign Bible Society in 1938, and published in Belgrade.
==References== {{reflist}}

{{Humanism}} '''Humanism in France''' found its way from [[Italy]], but did not become a distinct movement until the 16th century was well on its way.
On the completion of the [[Hundred Years' War]] between [[France]] and [[England]], the intellectual currents of [[humanism]] began to start. In 1464, [[Peter Raoul]] composed for the [[Philip III, Duke of Burgundy|Duke of Burgundy]] a history of [[Troy]]. At that time the French still regarded themselves as descendants of [[Hector]]. If we except Paris, none of the French universities took part in the movement. Individual writers and printing-presses at Paris, [[Lyon]], [[Rouen]] and other cities became its centres and sources. [[William Fichet]] and [[Robert Gaguin]] are usually looked upon as the first French Humanists. Fichet introduced "the eloquence of Rome" at Paris and set up a press at the Sorbonne. He corresponded with [[Bessarion]] and had in his library volumes of [[Petrarch]], [[Guarino of Verona]] and other Italians. Gaguin copied and corrected [[Suetonius]] in 1468 and other Latin authors. [[Gian Francesco Poggio Bracciolini|Poggio]]'s Jest-book and some of [[Lorenzo Valla|Valla]]'s writings were translated into French. In the reign of [[Louis XI]], who gloried in the title "the first Christian king", French poets celebrated his deeds. The homage of royalty took in part the place among the literary men of France that the cult of antiquity occupied in Italy.
[[Greek language|Greek]], which had been completely forgotten in France, had its first teachers in [[Gregory Tifernas]], who reached Paris, 1458, [[John Lascaris]], who returned with [[Charles VIII of France|Charles VIII]], and [[Hermonymus of Sparta]], who had [[Reuchlin]] and [[Budaeus]] (known variously as William Budaeus (English), Guillaume Budé (French) and Guilielmus Budaeus (Latin)) among his scholars. An impetus was given to the new studies by the Italian, [[Aleander]], afterwards famous for his association with [[Martin Luther]] at [[Worms, Germany|Worms]]. He lectured in Paris, 1509, on [[Plato]] and issued a ''Latino-Greek lexicon''. In 1512 his pupil, [[Vatable]], published the Greek grammar of [[Chrysoloras]]. [[Budaeus]], perhaps the foremost Greek scholar of his day, founded the [[Collège de France]], 1530, and finally induced [[Francis I of France|Francis I]] to provide for instruction in [[Biblical Hebrew language|Hebrew]] and Greek. The [[University of Paris]] at the close of the 14th century was sunk into a low condition and [[Erasmus]] bitterly complained of the food, the morals and the intellectual standards of the [[college of Montague]] which he attended. Budaeus urged the combination of the study of the Scriptures with the study of the classics and exclaimed of the [[Gospel of John]], "What is it, if not the almost perfect sanctuary of the truth!" [[Image:Francois Rabelais - Portrait.jpg|thumb|left|250px|[[François Rabelais]]]] [[Jacques Lefèvre d'Étaples]] studied in Paris, [[Pavia]], [[Padua]] and [[Cologne]] and, for longer or shorter periods, tarried in the greater Italian cities. He knew Greek and some Hebrew. From 1492–1506 he was engaged in editing the works of [[Aristotle]] and [[Raymundus Lullus]] and then, under the protection of [[Guillaume Briçonnet (Bishop of Meaux)|Guillaume Briçonnet]], [[bishop of Meaux]], he turned his attention to theology. It was his purpose to offset the ''Sentences'' of [[Peter the Lombard]] by a system of theology giving only what the [[Scriptures]] teach. In 1509, he published the ''Psalterum quintuplex'', a combination of five Latin versions of the Psalms, including a revision and a commentary by his own hand. In 1512, he issued a revised Latin translation of the [[Pauline Epistles]] with commentary. In this work, he asserted the authority of the Bible and the doctrine of justification by faith, without appreciating, however, the far-reaching significance of the latter opinion. Three years after the appearance of Luther's [[New Testament]], Lefevre's French translation appeared, 1523. It was made from the [[Vulgate]], as was his translation of the [[Old Testament]], 1528. In 1522 and 1525, appeared his commentaries on the four Gospels and the [[Catholic Epistles]]. The former was put on the Index by the [[Sorbonne]]. The opposition to the free spirit of inquiry and to the [[Protestant Reformation|Reformation]], which the Sorbonne stirred up and French royalty adopted, forced him to flee to [[Strassburg]] and then to the liberal court of [[Margaret of Angoulême]].
Among those who came into contact with Lefevre were [[Farel]] and [[John Calvin|Calvin]], the Reformers of [[Geneva]]. In the meantime [[Clément Marot]], 1495–1544, the first true poet of the French literary revival, was composing his French versification of the Psalms and of [[Ovid]]'s ''[[Metamorphoses]]''. The Psalms were sung for pleasure by French princes and later for worship in Geneva and by the [[Huguenot]]s. When Calvin studied the humanities and law at Bourges, [[Orléans]] and Paris, about 1520, he had for teachers Cordier and L'Etoile, the canonists, and [[Melchior Wolmar]], teacher of Greek, whose names the future Reformer records with gratitude and respect. He gave himself passionately to Humanistic studies and sent to Erasmus a copy of his work on Seneca's ''Clemency'', in which he quoted frequently from the ancient classics and the Fathers. Had he not adopted the new religious views, it is possible he would now be known as an eminent figure in the history of French Humanism.
==See also== [[Jest book]]
== Further reading == * [[Tzvetan Todorov]]. ''The Imperfect Garden: The Legacy of Humanism''. Princeton University Press. 2001. (text which focuses on the main views of French humanism)

{{Infobox Organization |name = Indiana University Dance Marathon |image = Indiana_University_Dance_Marathon_Logo.jpg |image_border = |size = |caption = |map = |msize = |mcaption = |abbreviation = IUDM |motto = For The Kids (FTK) |formation = 1991 |extinction = |type = |status = |purpose = Philanthropy |location = [[Bloomington, Indiana|Bloomington]], [[Indiana|IN]], [[United States|USA]] |region_served = |membership = |language = |leader_title = President |leader_name = David Luebbe (2018) |parent_organization = |affiliations = Riley Hospital for Children
Children's Miracle Network |num_staff = |num_volunteers =4,000+ |budget = |website = http://www.iudm.org/ |remarks = }} The '''Indiana University Dance Marathon''', commonly known as '''IU Dance Marathon''' or '''IUDM''',[http://www.iudm.org/?page_id=335 IUDM Nomenclature Guide]. is a 36-hour [[Dance Marathon]] that takes place every November at [[Indiana University Bloomington|Indiana University]] in [[Bloomington, Indiana|Bloomington]], [[Indiana]], [[United States]] with the purpose of raising both funding and awareness for pediatric care. In 1991, student Jill Stewart started IU Dance Marathon in honor of her friend, Ryan White, who died from AIDS the year before. Since then, IUDM has raised over $36 million for [[Riley Hospital for Children]] in [[Indianapolis, IN]], including $4,203,326.23 during the 2017 marathon year. The 2018 marathon took place November 2nd through November 4th and raised $4,187,051.23. ==History== [[Image:Ryan White.jpg|thumb|500px|right|Ryan White]] [[Image:Riley Hospital for Children.jpg|thumb|300px|right|Riley Hospital for Children in Indianapolis, IN]] ===Ryan White=== [[Ryan White]]'s 1990 death was the inspiration for the creation of the Indiana University Dance Marathon in 1991. Thirteen-year-old Ryan White contracted AIDS from contaminated blood transfusions he received for hemophilia. When news of the contraction of AIDS became public, his school district in Kokomo, Indiana banned him from attending classes. Ryan then went on to fight in court which led to many headlines across the country and national celebrities like Michael Jackson and Elton John advocated on his behalf. Michael Jackson and Elton John befriended Ryan and helped to spread his story and awareness of AIDS. After arduous court battles, Ryan won the right to return to school; but his battle with the community and AIDS had just begun. The White family dealt with adversity on a daily basis. People were not willing to deal with the concept of AIDS and shunned the Whites. They were victims of fear and anger but had an optimistic outlook that eventually things would return to normal. It was not until a bullet was shot into the White home that the family moved to Cicero, Indiana, where they found peace. Ryan White was one of the biggest advocates of AIDS awareness, appearing at schools and fundraisers across the nation and testified in front of the President's Commission on HIV Epidemic in hopes of changing the public's perception of the disease. On April 8, 1990, Ryan White died at the age of 18, right before he was to attend Indiana University.Johnson, Dirk (April 9, 1990). [https://www.nytimes.com/1990/04/09/obituaries/ryan-white-dies-of-aids-at-18-his-struggle-helped-pierce-myths.html "Ryan White Dies of AIDS at 18; His Struggle Helped Pierce Myths."] New York Times. Web. Retrieved May 28, 2014. His strength and acceptance of disease helped those battling common illnesses continue to fight. Ryan's life is commemorated by the annual Dance Marathon funds and the Ryan White Infectious Disease Center at Riley Hospital. ===Ashley Louise Crouse=== On Tuesday, April 12, 2005, the Indiana University campus suffered a loss with the death of one of its students, Ashley Louise Crouse. Ashley was the Vice President of Communications for IUDM and a member of [[Kappa Kappa Gamma]] sorority. On her way home from an executive meeting, Ashley was struck and killed by a drunk driver outside the sorority house in which she lived, leaving behind a legacy of hope and passion that continues to live within each person involved in the organization.Stefanski, Matt (October 28, 2012). [http://www.idsnews.com/news/story.aspx?id=89405 "Brother reflects on Ashley Crouse's IUDM legacy."] Indiana Daily Student. Indiana University. Web. Retrieved May 28, 2014. Born and raised in Carmel, Indiana, Ashley's hometown joined with IUDM to create the most successful high school dance marathon in the country. In addition, along with Ryan White, the two are remembered by the thousands of IU students each year during a walk of remembrance each spring.Dai, Michelle (February 27, 2014). [http://hilite.org/archives/34184 "Dance Marathon students should educate themselves on use of CHS Dance Marathon funds."] HiLite Online. Greyhound Media Network. Web. Retrieved May 28, 2014. ===Riley Hospital for Children=== [[Riley Hospital for Children]], the recipient of the proceeds of the dance marathon, is a nationally ranked pediatric hospital located on the [[Indiana University School of Medicine]]'s campus in [[Indianapolis, Indiana]]. It is one of the largest hospitals in the United States and treats over 80 percent of Hoosier children cancer patients.[http://iuhealth.org/riley/cancer/ "Cancer."] Riley Hospital for Children. Indiana University Health. N.d. Web. Retrieved May 28, 2014. It continues to be among the best in the nation for its innovative research and unparalleled care. For the third year in a row, Riley Hospital has been ranked nationally in all 10 categories by ''[[U.S. News and World Report]]'' [http://health.usnews.com/best-hospitals/area/in/riley-hospital-for-children-at-indiana-university-health-PA6420020 "Riley Hospital for Children Indiana University Health."] U.S. News and World Report. N.d. Web. Retrieved May 28, 2014. and remains the only nationally ranked children's hospital in the state of Indiana.[http://iuhealth.org/riley/about/recognition-honors/ "Recognition and Honors."] Riley Hospital for Children. Indiana University Health. N.d. Web. Retrieved May 28, 2014. The donations support Riley Hospital's mission to not turn away any child regardless of their families financial status. It has more care-beds than any other children's hospital and treats over 150,000 patients a year.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} Riley Hospital for children holds Indiana's only children's burn center and dialysis center.{{citation needed|date=March 2018}} It welcomes every type of patient and continues to enhance its cutting-edge care and facilities. IUDM funded the Ryan White Infectious Disease Center which is housed in the [http://iuhealth.org/riley/for-patients-and-families/simon-family-tower/ Simon Family Tower], a brand new 10-story, 675,000 sq. ft. inpatient center which opened on January 27, 2011.[http://iuhealth.org/newsroom/detail/riley-hospital-to-open-first-phase-of-simon-family-tower-in-january1/ "Riley Hospital to Open First Phase of Simon Family Tower in January."] Newsroom. Indiana University Health. N.d. Web. Retrieved May 28, 2014. The infectious disease center is led by the Director and Professor of Clinical Pediatrics, Dr. John C. Christenson, MD, along with the Associate Professor of Clinical Pediatrics, Dr. Elaine G. Cox, MD. Ryan White's doctor, Dr. Martin B. Kleiman, MD, continues to practice under infectious disease as the Ryan White Professor of Pediatrics.http://iuhealth.org/riley/infectious-diseases/infectious-diseases-team/ ==Events== {| class="wikitable" style="clear: right; float: right; margin-left: 40px;" |- ! style="background: #73C2FB; color: black; border: 1px solid black" colspan="3" | '''IUDM Through the Years''' |- | Year || Amount || Slogan |- | 1991 || $10,900.00 || "Celebrate life. Dance. Hope." |- | 1992 || $23,000.00 || "JAM!" |- | 1993 || $66,234.46 || "Do it for the children." |- | 1994 || $96,343.33 || "Together we will raise more in '94." |- | 1995 || $140,072.46 || "Keep the dream alive in '95." |- | 1996 || $152,760.00 || "Making miracles." |- | 1997 || $206,537.20 || "Big hearts helping little hands." |- | 1998 || $230,565.20 || "Living with hope, dancing for smiles." |- | 1999 || $315,060.16 || "Sharing smiles, living dreams." |- | 2000 || $402,324.17 || "A decade of chance, a lifetime of hope." |- | 2001 || $405,412.17 || "Dancing for miracles, reaching for dreams." |- | 2002 || $415,412.19 || "Believing in the gift of tomorrow." |- | 2003 || $403,000.19 || "The chance of a lifetime to give a lifetime of chance." |- | 2004 || $468,600.19 || "A chance of a lifetime to give a lifetime of chance." |- | 2005 || $677,415.19 || "If you can dream it, you can do it." |- | 2006 || $920,386.20 || "We dance because we can. we stand for those who can't." |- | 2007 || $1,041,197.20 || "Inspired by a cure. Touched by a story. Changed for a lifetime." |- | 2008 || $1,376,550.23 || "Have the heart to dream big and the passion to live bigger." |- | 2009 || $1,520,418.21 || "Encourage hope. Celebrate life. Dare to dream big." |- | 2010 || $1,602,713.20 || "Inspired by our past to dance for their future." |- | 2011 || $1,801,207.20 || "Out of difficulties grow miracles." |- | 2012 || $2,125,322.20 || "Where there is love, there is life." |- | 2013 || $2,622,123.21 || "Live for today. Dance for tomorrow." |- | 2014 || $3,206,340.22 || "Build Tomorrow's Dreams" |- | 2015 || $3,880,025.22 || "Bringing Legacy to Life" |- | 2016 || $4,152,440.23 || "United by Passion, Powered by Hope." |- | 2017 || $4,203,326.23 || "Founded in Family" |- |2018 |$4,187,051.203 |"Together We Will" |- | '''Total''' || '''$36,652,737.66''' || '''Total raised since 1991''' |} '''FT5K''' The IUDM FT5K is a 5K run/walk that occurs the spring before the marathon and is located across from the Indiana University football stadium. Participation is open public-wide and prizes are awarded to the top three finishers. Following the race, entertainment and food are provided, as well as, time to spend with the Riley kids.[https://www.idsnews.com/news/Directories/happenings/Default.aspx?eventid=14486 "IUDM Hosts FT5K to Support Riley Children's Hospital."] Indiana Daily Student. Indiana University. N.d. Web. Retrieved May 14, 2014. '''Road Rules''' Road Rules is a bi-annual canning effort where IUDM committee members form teams of 3-5 on either a Saturday or Sunday morning and are given specific locations within central and southern Indiana, usually consisting of grocery stores, restaurants and walking trails. '''A Walk to Remember''' Each year, around the anniversary of both Ryan White and Ashley Louise Crouse's deaths, hundreds of students gather to walk in memory of the pairs passing. The walk starts at the Kappa Kappa Gamma house, where Crouse was a member, and continues around campus until ending up back at the Kappa house.[http://www.iudm.org/?p=2693 "Ryan & Ashley Week to Take Over Campus."] Indiana University Dance Marathon. N.d. Web. Retrieved May 28, 2014. '''Fore the Kids Golf Outing''' The IUDM Golf Outing is the main summer event and takes place at the River Glen Golf Club in Fishers, IN. Last year, the annual outing raised a record $31,000, surpassing 2012's total of $28,000. Individuals are encouraged to create teams to participate in the tournament in addition to a lunch and silent auction. To kick off the tournament, Riley patients and families are invited to share their story and encourage the golfers during their competition.[http://www.iudm.org/?p=1939 "IUDM's Golf Outing was a Success!"] Indiana University Dance Marathon. N.d. Web. Retrieved May 28, 2014. '''Runway Riley''' Runway Riley is an annual fashion show co-sponsored by IU Dance Marathon and [[Phi Mu]] sorority. Not only does the event showcase the year's newest line of IUDM apparel for the first time to the public, but Riley kids and their families are featured as models of the clothing and merchandise. Immediately after the show, all apparel is available for purchase. Since its introduction in September 2012, Runway Riley has raised almost $30,000 FTK. The Riley kids get to feel like superstars in front of hundreds of cheering attendees.Schumacher, Torie (September 10, 2013). [http://www.idsnews.com/news/story.aspx?id=93988 "Patients take runway for IUDM"] Indiana Daily Student. Web. Retrieved May 12, 2014. '''Gala''' The Gala, IUDM's largest singular fundraising event, is a formal event held in Indianapolis, Indiana every October. The Special Events committee host a dinner featuring speakers and both a silent and no-reserve auction This event raised nearly $100,000 in 2013.Benveniste, Alexis. [http://theodysseyonline.com/indiana/iudm-gala-a-hit-for-iu-students/9070 "IUDM Gala: A Hit for IU Students."] The Odyssey. Web. Retrieved May 28, 2014. '''Riley at the Rock''' Each year, IUDM partners with Indiana University Athletics to host a pre-game tailgate featuring food, music, and games during which Riley children (over 60 in 2013) and their families spend time with IUDM participants. Following these pre-game festivities, the families and IUDM students enjoy the unique opportunity of running across the field immediately before the start of the game. Riley at the Rock provides an opportunity for the students to interact with children that have inspired them to participate in IUDM outside of the marathon.Hawkins, Angela. [http://www.idsnews.com/news/story.aspx?id=95065 "IUDM and Riley event draws patients, parents."] Indiana Daily Student. Web. Retrieved June 1, 2014. '''IUDM Gives Back''' IUDM Gives Back is an effort in which dance marathon committee members have the opportunity to give back to the Bloomington community through volunteer work. Committee members volunteer for various establishments including the Monroe County Community Kitchen, [[Boys & Girls Clubs of America]], the [[Bloomington Community Orchard]], and the [[WonderLab|WonderLab Museum of Science, Health & Technology]]. '''For The Kicks''' An annual event where IUDM partners with the [[Indiana Hoosiers men's soccer]] for a night of fun, leading up to the team's home game that night. ==Marathon Weekend== {{sources|section|date=March 2018}}
[[Image:Video-x-generic.svg|left]][https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=IdQZoqfmHqk IUDM 2013 Line Dance]
[[Image:IUDM 2013 Crowd.jpg|thumb|200px|right|IUDM 2013]] [[Image:IUDM 2013 Total.jpg|thumb|200px|right|IUDM 2013 Total]] The marathon takes place at the Indiana University Tennis Center, located on campus just north of [[Assembly Hall (Bloomington)|Assembly Hall]] and [[Memorial Stadium (Indiana)|Memorial Stadium]], from Friday to Sunday one weekend in November. Those volunteering, or dancing, stand for 12, 24, or 36 hours in honor of those who cannot. Before the event, all dancers participate in Color Wars fall semester long competition between 8 color teams that compete during the months leading up to the marathon and throughout the duration of the 36 hour dance marathon event. Dancer organizations are randomly divided into color teams and work together to earn points for their color by participating in weekly competitions, fundraising, 3 large-scale events, marathon stage games, and marathon participation. The winner of color wars for the year is announced at the marathon just before the raising of the total. Committee members come together to set up, run the event and inspire others for the duration of the weekend. The marathon starts at 8 PM Friday night with dancers running into the gym to the song, "[[Eye of the Tiger]]." The executive council is then introduced and the dancers get to witness the famous IUDM Linedance for the first time. After the opening ceremonies, the teams are split up in a variety of stations around the center, including stations geared toward learning the linedance, hospitality and sports activities. At certain times all teams and committee members come together to hear artist and speakers perform, participate in activities on stage and listen to Riley stories. Every year, IUDM has many visitors during the duration of the marathon, including IU alumni, faculty and administration, donors, and most importantly, the Riley families. Everyone at the marathon gathers to meet and listen to dozens of Riley children tell their stories. Each Riley kid walks down a red carpet, through the crowd, and up onto the stage, as each participant cheers them onward. During theirs presentations, the room falls silent and everyone uses this moment as a reminder of why they are standing. As the marathon comes to a conclusion, the presidential address is given and all participants gather to remember those to which they stand for. Finally, the total is raised officially marking the end of the marathon and showing the hard work put in by thousands over the course of the year. In 2018, IUDM raised $4,187,051.23. IUDM 2018 will take place from November 2nd through the 4th. ==Organization Structure== {{sources|section|date=March 2018}} {| class="wikitable" style="clear: right"; float: center; style="background: black; color: white"; style="border: 3px solid black;" |- ! colspan="4" style="background: gainsboro; color: black" style="border: 1px solid black" | '''President''' |- ! colspan="4" style="background: gainsboro; color: black" style="border: 1px solid black" | '''Vice Presidents (4)''' |- | align="center" width="180" style="background: #73C2FB; color: black; border: 1px solid black" | Communications || style="background: #74C365; [[Image:The Earth seen from Apollo 17.jpg|thumb|right|The [[Earth]] seen from [[Apollo 17]]]]
The '''International Day for Biological Diversity''' (or '''World Biodiversity Day''') is a [[United Nations]]–sanctioned [[International observances|international day]] for the promotion of [[biodiversity]] issues. It is currently held on [[May 22]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Convention on Biological Diversity (CBD) page for IBD |url=http://www.cbd.int/idb/|accessdate=2011-04-21}}</ref>
The International Day for Biological Diversity falls within the scope of the UN Post-2015 Development Agenda's [[Sustainable Development Goals]]. In this larger initiative of international cooperation, the topic of biodiversity concerns stakeholders in [[sustainable agriculture]]; [[desertification]], [[land degradation]] and drought; [[right to water|water]] and [[sanitation]]; health and [[sustainable development]]; energy; science, technology and innovation, [[knowledge-sharing]] and capacity-building; [[urban resilience]] and adaptation; [[sustainable transport]]; [[climate change]] and [[disaster risk reduction]]; oceans and seas; forests; [[social vulnerability|vulnerable groups]] including [[indigenous peoples]]; and [[food security]].<ref>{{Cite web|title = 1554TST_compendium_issues_briefs_rev1610.pdf|url = https://docs.google.com/gview?url=http://sustainabledevelopment.un.org/content/documents/1554TST_compendium_issues_briefs_rev1610.pdf&embedded=true|website = docs.google.com|accessdate = 2015-05-21}}</ref> The critical role of biodiversity in sustainable development was recognized in a [http://www.unece.org/index.php?id=29343&L=0 Rio+20] outcome document, "The World We Want: A Future for All".
From its creation by the Second Committee of the [[United Nations General Assembly|UN General Assembly]] in 1993 until 2000, it was held on December 29 to celebrate the day the [[Convention on Biological Diversity]] went into effect. On December 20, 2000,<ref name="RP"> {{cite journal |author= [[Victor Giurgiu]] |title= Simpozionul "Biodiversitatea pădurilor din România", dedicat "Zilei Internaționale a Biodiversității" |language= ro |journal= [[Revista pădurilor|Rev. pădur.]] |issn= 1583-7890 |volume= 126 |issue= 3–4 |pages= 104–106 |date=Sep 2011
|url= http://www.revistapadurilor.ro/(16753) |id= 16753 |accessdate= 2012-05-30 }}(webpage has a translation button) </ref> the date was shifted to commemorate the adoption of the Convention on May 22, 1992 at the Rio [[Earth Summit]], and partly to avoid the many other holidays that occur in late December.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Millennium Ecosystem Assessment |url=http://www.maweb.org/en/index.aspx |accessdate=2011-04-21 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20110423003943/http://www.maweb.org/en/index.aspx |archivedate=2011-04-23 |df= }}</ref>
==Activities== Coinciding with the observance of International Day for Biological Diversity, on May 2011 [[Indonesia]]n Forestry Minister inaugurated the Ciwalen Canopy Trail that is {{convert|120|m}} long and {{convert|60|m}} wide at an elevation of {{convert|30|–|40|m}} above the ground at [[Gunung Gede Pangrango National Park]], [[West Java]], to accommodate five to ten people in one trip.<ref>http://www.antaranews.com/en/news/71957/forestry-minister-inaugurates-ciwalen-canopy-trail</ref>
The 2014 theme of Island Biodiversity was chosen because islands provide a rich source of biodiversity for plants, animals, fish and forestry products. Many indigenous fruits and [[Leaf vegetable|green leafy vegetables]] are rich in [[micronutrient]]s. According to the [[Secretariat of the Pacific Community]], two out of every three deaths can be attributed to [[Non-communicable disease]]s (NCDs). These can result from a change in diets linked to consumption of highly processed imported products, while local crop species are abandoned or reduced in the local diet. As a consequence, island representatives meeting in Addis Ababa, Ethiopia in May, 2014 stressed that serious consideration should be given to more research and policy action with the aim of increasing diet diversity.<ref>{{cite web|title=Africa, the Caribbean and the Pacific need more research and policy intervention to stem the reduction in (bio)diversity in the diet|url=http://cta.int/en/article/2014-05-21/africa-the-caribbean-and-the-pacific-need-more-research-and-policy-intervention-to-stem-the-reductio.html|publisher=CTA|accessdate=22 May 2014}}</ref>
